Being of Cameron Mitchell fame, it isn't a surprise that this is the best Asian restaurant in Delaware County.The service is solid. Not "five-star" like you'd get at M or Eddie Merlots but very capable and effective.I've never had a meal here that wasn't well prepared. The Black Pepper Steak being tonight's sampling. The brown sauce was a bit too much near the end, but everything was well cooked and served well.

Pretty disappointed ...Let me start by saying I like Cam. Mitchell restaurants; I have dinner at one about every 12 or 14 days. They are generally very good. I took my friend to Happy Hour at Molly Woo's on TUE Dec. 31. I confirmed online that afternoon that Happy Hour was M-F 3 pm to 7 pm. We got there at 5:45 - only to sit down and then be told they weren't serving Happy Hour because of New Year's Eve. I would have no problem with that - except that the website indicated they had Happy Hour and the little table tents in the bar listed their Happy Hour options. Totally disappointing after having made the drive to Polaris. We went to Asian Gourmet instead. I'm not swearing off Cam. Mitchell restaurants, but I think I will take a break from them for JAN and FEB off to check out some other Central Ohio options.

I gotta say... I really like Molly Woo's.  I am so not a fan of chain-type establishments, in general... especially in malls.  Blech.  However, Molly Woo's is doing something right in my book.  I've eaten here a few times - today being the most recent - and I'm impressed.  They have great service and are happy to accomodate my vegan requests.  I ordered a couple of vegetable rolls today for take-out.  I was starting to wonder what in the heck was taking so long (as in, I waited about 20 minutes at 2 in the afternoon for my food...), but it was worth the wait.  When I got home, my veggie rolls were fresh and delicious and even artfully presented in the lame little plastic container.  Cute.  When I'm in Polaris and don't feel like gambling on a place that may or may not "get" the vegan thing, I'll definitely head back to Molly Woo's for consistently great service and yummy food.

Pretty nice place. Service is pretty friendly.  My girlfriend likes the crab rangoons. We weren't crazy about the Hunan chicken, but the firecracker chicken was good.  It's very open and seems pretty loud in there.  I'd recommend it for a casual dinner, but not for an intimate dinner.

The short rib appetizer was cold and meat tasted stale. The waiter brought a new one and it was complete night and day... Ended up being good! Then ordered lettuce cups...found 3 long strands of hair at the top. Ewww! Waiter provided great service through it all. I felt bad that he and we had to deal with the faults of the chef.

The decor is amazing and the food great (War Sui Gai).  You'll need to order tea.  They serve green teas; however, I'm not sure if they serve Shui Hsien.  Missing are the Asian staff and round tables.  In my experience the staff is attentive and facilitated dialog with the kitchen that enabled quick adjustments for dietary constraints (substituted broccoli for mushrooms and changed cooking oil).  The menu could be more readable--and the fortune in the cookie was questionable (no one could confirm the correct pronunciation for the word 'vegetable' in Chinese).  Enjoy!http://bit.ly/j5lYiyhttp://news.yahoo.com/reports-woman-catches-toddler-fell-10-stories-110342299.html

Was promptly greeted and shown to our table. We did eat an early supper that I'm sure helped with that. Food and service were very good. Atmosphere was very nice. I had the beef (very tender) and asparagus dish. Will go back again if at the mall.

Thai Basil Scallops...best meal ever!!! I have been to Molly Woo's several times, and have tried everything with either Shrimp and/ or Scallops. I love both Shrimp and Scallops, but my hubby does not, so it is therefore my "go to" item when we go out. Most of the dishes I have had here were good, but a little too spicy for me. Then I tried the Thai Basil Scallops...just the right amount of sweetness to really enjoy the yummy scallops! Heading back to Molly Woo's for our Office Christmas party this week! We have been here before with a larger group, and they placed us at one of the big round tables, away from the rest of the tables and booths. It made for easier conversation. They also have a separate dining area near the bar that has sliding doors to close it off from the main dining room.

The service is great and the place looks nice but the food is just blah. It's not bad, like eww gross spit it out, but it just doesn't taste good. We got several appetizers to try and several entrees to share and the only thing ok was the ribs. I would suggest going some place else.

The middle part of February has been dubbed 'hell week' by my boyfriend and I, who celebrate our anniversary, Valentine's Day, and his birthday all within an eight day span. This past Friday, we celebrated two of the three 'holidays' with a dinner at Molly Woo's. Neither of us had been there before.We meant to go out on Wednesday when there were fewer people, but we ended up going out on Friday, the day before Valentine's Day, at peak dinner time. It was hard for us to find a parking spot, and it would have been smarter to call ahead for reservations. The place was packed, and we had to wait about thirty-five minutes for a table, but there were cushioned couches and chairs to wait in, and I could tell the hostesses were doing there best to ferret out empty tables.While we waited, I enjoyed the decor. It was super China themed, all red with lots of jellyfish lanterns hanging from the ceiling. They had real bamboo trees flagging the entrance, and lots of pottery and Chinese carved wood. They managed to achieve an upscale Chinese theme and totally avoid tackiness - kudos for not having a stereotypical Koi pond or photos of the Great Wall.Our waiter, Jason, was awesome. He was friendly and knowledgeable, and he took good care of us. We started the night with drinks. Greg got a boring old beer. I got the Godzilla - a mix of OJ, pineapple juice, and Midori. It came with an umbrella - tres chic! I couldn't really taste the Midori. It was more like a super pineapple-y fruit punch.From there it was on to apps. I had the Crab Rangoon, and Greg had the Chicken Lettuce Cups. If you've read any of my past Chinese food reviews, you'll know that I have been hard pressed to find good Crab Rangoon in Columbus. Molly Woo's is the best I've had thus far. The shells were thin and crispy, and they were loaded with filling. We were expecting little muffin-tin shaped lettuce containers for our Chicken Lettuce Cups, but the dish was more like a Chinese burrito. The lettuce came out like a stack of tortillas with a chicken/scallion/water chestnut mixture on the side. It was DIY from there. The menu said the Cups were supposed to be spicy. I don't care much for heat, but I was able to handle the Lettuce Cups with no problem at all.For dinner, I chose the Pineapple Chicken (a compliment to my Godzilla drink) and Greg - without the option of his standard General Tso's - went for the Beef and Broccoli. The meals were family-sized, larger than I expected. The Pineapple Chicken was fantastic! It was the whitest, juiciest Chinese food chicken I've ever had. The pieces were large and crisp. The sweet and sour sauce was just right, and they didn't skimp on the pineapples (the best part of any sweet and sour dish). Greg really enjoyed his Beef and Broccoli too.Sadly, we were stuffed from our apps. I ate about 1/3 of my entree before declaring my defeat. Greg, who never walks out with a box, also had to have his meal packaged. And still, our waiter sold us on dessert, a limited edition lemon cheesecake with blueberry and whipped cream topping. Granted, we had it boxed too.Molly Woo's is near the top of my Cameron Mitchell Restaurant list. I can't wait to go back. If I could, I'd give them 4.5 stars.

I used to live in Columbus and when I did, I frequented Molly Woos as often as possible.  I don't consider myself an expert on Chinese food, as the only thing that I really like is sweet and sour chicken.  Molly Woo's has a comparable dish called Pineapple Chicken - it is my favorite dish of all time!Try to go during happy hour - half priced appetizer's!  The lettuce cups are delicious and the spring rolls are pretty good too.The decor is great - high ceilings, lots of paper lanterns hanging everywhere.  The wait staff are always friendly and the prices are "reasonable".The only negative I can say about coming to Molly Woos is the parking!  It's in the center of the mall if you are coming to the mall just to eat at MW, you'll have to park a mile away.  Fortunately, they have valet parking just outside of the restaurant.

For the last two years my daughter has had her birthday dinner at Molly Woos. We normally get dumplings, crab rangoon, cashew chicken and firecracker chicken. The food is out of this world and the service is top notch. NEVER had a bad experience. My personal favorite is the cashew chicken. The chicken has great flavor, covered in a incredible brown sauce and shares the plate with a million cashews and pea pods. Another reason we go is because Molly celebrates b-days in style. They let the birthday person pick a dessert on the menu for free. See our picture. This year we got a egg roll banana. Unbelievable. I wasn't sure I was going to survive. Incredible.

The service was great and they were very accommodating.  The server almost encouraged us to make substitutions and customizations with the menu which was a nice change.  We ate family style so I got to try a lot of different dishes.  The Shrimp Pad Thai was probably my favorite with just the right amount of kick.  The other food was good as well, but nothing stood out as amazing.

I was taken on a date here a while ago. I had never tried Molly Woo's and since I love Chinese food, I was pretty excited about trying out this new place.It was hard for us to find a place to park. Molly Woo's is located in the Polaris Mall, so it shares the mall parking lot. I think you can get into the restaurant from the mall, but they also have a huge entrance so you don't even have to go to the mall at all, but you do have to deal with that parking situation. They have valet parking, where you can just pull your car up to the front entrance under this balcony area, but we didn't do that. We had to drive around a bit to find and spot and when we did, it was sort of far away. I never mind the walking, but it was winter so it was cold out.When we got inside I couldn't believe how red everything was! I guess that is the theme that they're going for. The walls are red, the lights were red, so everything had this reddish glow. It looked kind of cool but I felt like I was on the set of some Kung-Fu movie where the evil Chinese drug lord would come out from behind a curtain and start a gun war. It didn't quite feel like just a restaurant. I'm happy to say, however, that I did not see any evil Chinese drug lords. Just servers and food. But I can't say for sure what went on in the back room...I'm kidding. I'll stop.We waited at the hostess area and there was a little bit of a wait - not much. It was a Friday or Saturday night around 8, so it's fair that it was a little busy. We didn't even have to wait 5 minutes until a table was ready, however, and we were seated at a booth on the edge of the dining room. I was happy about this because I always prefer booths and considered myself lucky because most of the seating here seems to be tables.Our hostess said our server would be right with us. She wasn't. It took her a while to show up and take our drink order. After that, even longer for her to show up to take our dinner order. Usually I don't mind, unless I'm in a hurry or something, but I hate dates. And this one wasn't one of the better ones in my life. So sitting and waiting meant suffering through more date conversation. I realized that perhaps my opinion of Molly Woo's is skewed because of the circumstance I was in, but I'm trying to remain objective here. And this just happened to be one of the times that I was not happy about the server's spotty appearances. I just wanted to get this dinner over with.Finally she came back and we could order. Luckily we skipped the appetizers and I opted for the Cashew Chicken. I wanted to try something a little different than Cashew Chicken, which they have at every Chinese place, but it seemed to be one of the only chicken dishes at Molly Woo's which wasn't fried. I just wasn't in the mood for fried or breaded chicken and although the Honey Chicken sounded good, it was fried. The Pineapple Chicken also sounded good but it was fried. So I went with the cashews since there weren't a lot of other options. Oh well. I suppose that I could have asked to substitute, but you know, sometimes on first dates you don't want to appear all picky. Bad first impression.An even longer wait for the food. Sure, there were a lot of tables, but really? I know that it probably seemed long because I was itching to get out of there, but in all reality it probably did take our food between 25-30 minutes to be placed in front of us. My cashew chicken looked pretty good. My date ordered some kind of seafood dish with shrimp. He was telling me about how he loved this place and came here all the time and that was why he brought me here. He told me how good everything was, so I was expecting it to be so great since he kept raving about it. But my chicken? Quite mediocre. It tasted just about like every other cashew chicken I've had, which was mostly been carryout from little Chinese to go joints. From his talking the place up, to the fancy decor of the interior, to the valet parking, to the fact that Molly Woo's is a Cameron Mitchell restaurant, I guess that I was expecting a little more flavor, a little more oomph. The chicken was ultimately pretty plain. It was good, and the chicken was at least quality meat, but there was nothing really special about the dish. Nevertheless, I was happy to be moving the date along and proceeded to enjoy my chicken and white rice.I think that I might give Molly Woo's another chance someday, maybe I'll just have to try something different on the menu. And I've since heard good things about their appetizers. Perhaps they do deserve another chance. But I all in all wasn't exactly wowed by their choices on the menu, either. They seemed to offer what you can get at Chinese restaurants anywhere else, and if the Cashew Chicken was any indication, it will probably taste the same as anywhere else, too. Which isn't necessarily bad, but I think that Molly Woo's is a bit more expensive than most other places, probably just because it's Cameron Mitchell.

I came here for a birthday party with friends, and I went in sort of expecting to dislike it based on the categorization of most of the vegetarian dishes as "sides" (and they are in fact smaller than the entrees) and the generally boring menu.  On one of the happier notes of my visit, my expectation was met.The food itself wasn't _bad_.  People seemed generally satisfied.  The Molly's Feast (aka the only vegetarian entree) wasn't very big, but was ok.  However, I asked for it spicy and received it smothered in chili paste.  The friend to my right asked for her curry noodles spicy and they had no noticeable heat.  Also, my "garden roll" was pretty much flavorless and constructed with microgreens that were definitely off-peak (yellowing, spotted).  On a fun note, every. single. vegetarian dish on the menu is served "in garlic sauce."The service was not so great.  Granted, we were a large party, so allowances should be made.  My server failed to refill waters during the entree when I actually needed it (see: chili-inundated vegetables) and got my rice order wrong.  At one point he asked the table, "wait, how many steamed rices were there?" as though expecting us to have counted.  They also ran out of martini glasses.  How do you run out of martini glasses at a large restaurant with a large martini section on your menu?The prices, while not outrageous, were not a great deal for almost completely ordinary Americanized Chinese food. ($5-6 for apps and desserts, $10-$15 for entrees).Last but not least, the coffee was lukewarm and not particularly good.  People did seem generally pleased with the desserts, though.In summary, Cameron Mitchell apparently sat down one day and said to himself, "I want to copy P.F. Chang's!"  While both have nearly-over-the-top Asian-themed decor and cater well to Midwesterners, P.F. Chang's has better food, better service, and a more extensive and interesting menu.  I'd go back to Molly Woo's, but probably only if someone else were paying.  And driving.  2.5 stars.

It was really busy here the night we decided to go.... Encouraged by a gift card. Put our name in to sit at a table and we were told there was a good wait. We wandered into the bar and sat down and decided we were fine with eating there. Bartenders were awesome and our food was out fast. Loved the samurai roll and caterpillar roll. I devoured the house salad. The dressing was fantastic! My boyfriend got the firecracker chicken and it too was wonderful... Just the right amount of sweet and spicy... Like me haha.
Very good food. Could be a little spicier, but amazing.  I have a food allergy and they were awesome in catering to my needs! Couldn't ask for a better dinner :)

Here's a simple one.Parking Sucks.Wait staff is usually good, but inconsistent.Crab Rangoon is OMG SEND ME TO HEAVENFirecracker Chicken is "see above"The Tofu is great and definitely the best I've had, and I don't care for Tofu.Enjoy!

My wife and I have wanted to try this place for a long time because we have heard good things and it has a gluten-free menu (As do all Mitchell's restaurants).  My wife enjoyed the food very much I on the other hand was not that big of a fan. The spring rolls and sweet/sour sauce were bland and my main dish of Mongolian something was just ehh.  The service was excellent; the waitress guided me through my indecisiveness without any outward discontent. They do have a good selection of gluten-free items and if we go back it will be because of that. Otherwise if we want that kind of Chinese food we will stick with PF Changs.

I really enjoy Molly Woo's even though I feel like it should fall into the guilty-pleasure category.  As Mike S mentioned, the service is always great and while I've occasionally had to wait, it's never too brutal and you can get some shopping done in the meantime.  I really like the decor as well and think that it adds a fun ambiance.I always order the same thing - the spring rolls and Molly's Feast (crispy tofu and assorted vegetables in brown sauce).  The staff has always been very nice about substituting some vegetables for other - I always substitute the tomatoes for baby corn.  The mixed drinks are good as well and not too strong.This is probably the most affordable Cameron Mitchell restaurant and my personal favorite.

Cameron Mitchell does Americanized Chinese. Pros: Quick, friendly service; good menu selection; delicious food; well decorated; generous portion sizes for entrÌ©es.Cons: too fast (25 minutes total from sit down to meal completion); tad overpriced.My boyfriend took me to Molly Woos at Polaris. This restaurant is part of the mall, not its own building; so most of the patrons are mall guests. We found parking just fine...I thought the restaurant was nicely decorated and the space was well designed. The paper lanterns were abundant, and repetitive but nice and the other details were well thought-out.We had made a reservation, but there probably was no need since the dining room was only half full (7:30p on a Friday night). Our table was one of the booths near the south windows. Even though the dining room was half full, it was loud. Our waiter was prompt, friendly, polite, and helpful. She had good menu recommendations, she was quick to refill a drink or to take another order, and her timing for food arrival was perfect. She was professional, not trying to chat up our table or hover over us. This type of service is the reason why I love Cameron Mitchell restaurants.I ordered the white tangerine tea, which is infused in its own cast iron pot and served in a tiny tea cup. The tea was very good, however the tea was too strong near the end of the pot (mostly my fault for letting it sit for too long). My boyfriend ordered a Sapporo.For appetizers I ordered Crab Rangoons (I simply love them). They were delicious; six small crab rangoon pouches. No unnecessary fried wonton, real crab meat, not super sweet. The sauce that accompanies was a zesty,  but I preferred them without the sauce. My boyfriend ordered a bowl of the wonton soup.For the main course I had the Cashew Chicken. The plate was big enough to feed two, with an overabundance of cashews. I would have liked a little more chicken because I felt that there were too many cashews and too much sauce, which overpowered the completed dish. I thought that the overall combination of ingredients was traditional to a cashew chicken dish and very delicious. My boyfriend ordered the Fircracker Chicken. This dish would've been perfect if it were spicier (but we choose our spice level so that was our own fault). The chicken was cooked perfectly and each piece was coated in the delectable sauce. I loved the thai chilies in the sauce. There were no survivors with this dish and we found it hard not to soak up the sauce in the rice and eat it all. Both of us ordered fried rice (a simple vegetable, fried rice).My leftover cashew chicken and rice was even better for lunch the following day :-)Ending check total: around $50, excluding tip. Total Time Elapsed (from the time that we entered the restaurant to when we paid the check): 25 minutes. Classy fast food.Final Recommendation: Good for lunch, too pricey for dinner; LOVE the Firecracker Chicken.

Molly Woo's Asian Bistro's location does it a service. It's located on the far north side at Polaris, where the mall shoppers don't know any better. It's atmosphere is much better than the average Asian restaurant, as is its food presentation. The flavors are average. Perhaps the draw is eating at a Cameron Mitchell restaurant -- the only Asian restaurant in its fleet of local eateries -- at an affordable price. Unlike other reviewers, the vegetarian friends I visited with found the restaurant to be very veg-friendly. Still, if I'm on the north side and craving Asian food, I'll visit Asian Gourmet at Morse and Hamilton. What is lost in ambiance is gained in taste.

Over the top Asian decor and overpriced Americanized Chinese food describes Molly Woo's perfectly.  I don't really mean this as a complaint as the food tasted just fine and the service was good, but there are certainly better options in the Columbus area if you're looking to curb a Chinese food craving.

I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this place!!! Molly Woo's is one of the best asian restaurants in town! Every time I've been there the food was phenomenal and the best!! We only get to Molly Woo's a few times a year, but it is worth it!! The atmosphere, the waiters and the entire place is worth spending your money!!!

Indifferent and bored. That would be the best way to describe the food at Molly Woo's, which is really disappointing seeing as how Molly's Woo's is a Cameron Mitchell Joint.Oh, you'll be tempted to go inside, the decorations and atmosphere are fantastic! 5 stars for sure. Nothing says "Chinese" like RED, and Molly Woo's is covered in Martha Stewart's "Commie Red", which is totally in this season.The incredibly high ceilings and with paper lanterns, the back wall covered in Chinese "artifacts", these things all add to the aura of a mystical dining experience. But that's about where the magic ends and reality starts to set in when the appetizers come out.Now when you see Spring Rolls on the menu for $5.95, how many do you think you are getting? We guessed 4. We were wrong. 2 Spring Rolls for $5.95 = $2.98 a roll. Hm. We munched in silence but I know we were both thinking "I hope this isn't a preview of what's to come". That's not to say these Spring Rolls tasted bad, in fact they were quite good! But at almost $3 a roll, I felt a little shorted.Well next up was the main course. I ordered the Pineapple Chicken ($10.95) which I quickly learned meant "Fancy name for Sweet & Sour Chicken" and my boyfriend ordered Honey Chicken ($12.95). Both dishes come with your choice of fried, white, or brown rice. We both opted for fried. Now, the chicken was good in both dishes. Not grisly, not overly fried or doughy. Good quality chicken meat was used. But the dishes themselves were lacking any sort of style of flare. The Honey Chicken was supposed to be served in a "spicy honey sauce" but there was nothing spicy about it! Not even if you take into consideration the wimpy Americanized version of spicy that often gets served. There was nothing wrong with the portions served. Given the quality of ingredients and money paid I'd say that the portions were just right. But is it too much of me to expect something more from a Cameron Mitchell Joint? Where's the flare? The culinary expertise? That something special that sets Molly Woo's apart from any other Chinese sit down restaurant? Nothing. Nada. Not there. Other than the quality of ingredients used, there was nothing setting this meal apart than a meal at Number One Chinese. Except for the price.Well dessert picked up my mood a little as I ordered the Banana Spring Rolls. I'd say they were the most innovative thing on the menu! And delicious to boot.Overall we left feeling a little cheated out of a nice dining experience. Cameron, you're 1-2 with me. I think you owe me something special spectacular.

Food was good but even spicy dishes are never very spicy. Service was great. I recommend this restaurant but honestly if I had a choice between Molly Woo's and PF Chang's, I would go with Chang's. I feel the overall taste of food at Chang's is more robust.

A very nice casual Chinese restaurant with tasty and fresh oriental food. I really like their lettuce wraps. The service there is very good when they are not too busy. I always bring home leftovers so plan accordingly when ordering.

Having just relocated back to Columbus from New York after almost 20 years, I found myself looking for local restaurants. My girlfriend, who is Flipino badly needed a white rice fix, and my mom doesn't really like chinese, but sugested this place or the Lucky House in Westerville. Fearing the other choice may be the UNLucky House, we went here. Well, it was ok for what it was, a kind of New Pan-Asian cuisine. I had chicken that was fried with a spicy sauce. Can't actually remember the name of the dish, which isn't good. The food was OK, but nothing to write home about, the service was good (my normally penny pinching mom left 20%), and the decor was pretty good. I guess I would eat here again, but I prefer more of a homestyle place that specializes in one cuisine, like Shanghainese, for example. It wasn't awful, but it didn't leave a lasting impression. I would, however, go again, especially if someone else is paying the bill.
It's a decent Americanized Chinese place, definitely better then the food court

Cool place, upscale Chinese but the place doesn't take itself too seriously. Fun menu, prices aren't outrageous. Like all the Cameron Mitchell restaurants, service is terrific and the food will not disappoint. Definitely worth a try!
i had their dan dan noodle last time. it is pretty good. service is good too. will be back again sometime

I think this might be one of my favorite restaurants of all time in Columbus.  Firstly, the atmosphere is classy but also casual; the vibe is similar to some of my favorite places in New York and Chicago  (I tend to shun formal/fussy restaurants).  And it is the only place where I can count on fresh, delicious oysters.  Better oysters than I've had on either coast, though I don't understand how that's possible.  How they do it, I do not know.But probably my favorite thing is the service.  Why is it that every time I visit The Pearl, I feel as though they have gotten advance notice that an important restaurant reviewer is there (incognito), and that they need to make everything the very best it can be?  As though they have been rehearsing for the night I come in (by some odd coincidence)?  This is typical of Cameron Mitchell restaurants,  but especially so at The Pearl.  I love this place.

I live one block from The Pearl and have only been here twice. I went for the first time about three years ago on a summer night. We had an excellent table right by the windows which were wide open so we got to sit there and enjoy the weather and peoplewatch. It was fantastic. Absolute 5/5 for atmosphere. I wasn't crazy about anything on the menu. I asked the server for his opinion and he recommended the Hanger Steak. I honestly didn't really like it (and I love steak and burgers so that's not good). I felt like it was a tad too spicy for my palate which made it unenjoyable (kind of frustrating since I asked the server if it was spicy and he said no.) To top it off, I got sick that night (not related to the food) so after being nauseous and whatnot I was never crazy about going back. But that was over three years ago and it is long overdue to give The Pearl a second chance! I had heard great things about their brunch so my friend and I went there while she was in town from Cali. Again, I absolutely loved the atmosphere. It's sophisticated, elegant  and a touch of hipster. What I loved was that my friend and I were sat in a booth and even though it was super busy and there was music playing, I could have a very simple conversation with her at normal volume. I swear I feel like any time I go to some of the High St restaurants I feel like I'm having to scream across the table because of loud music, clamoring plates, etc. Anyways I once again asked the server for recommendations (risky move given my last experience). He told me that the chicken and waffles were the number one choice by other customers followed by the Short Rib Poutine. I turned to Yelp to review pics and settled on the chicken and waffles although the poutine looked good as well! The chicken and waffles were great!! I know this sounds crazy but I've never actually had chicken & waffles before (hopefully admitting that doesn't get me kicked off of Yelp!). I always thought that the two flavors wouldn't mix well but I was obviously wrong. The chicken here had great flavor and a light coating mixed with various spices. It comes with blueberry syrup but I opted for regular maple syrup which was great. The waffle was light and fluffy; the perfect size as well! I was able to eat everything and feel comfortably full---the perfect amount of food! I would definitely like to go back to try the poutine for brunch and the fish and chips for lunch or dinner sometime. The atmosphere cannot be beat and I'm quickly finding that there are many great entree options to test out. I'll be back soon!

Consistently a great experience.I have ragged on this place so much for being an Oyster bar - in the middle of the MidWest. It just seems...åÊwell...åÊwrong.Plus, when Gordon Ramsay came, he ordered *the burger*.So I joked about *that*. But that burger...åÊlooked tasty.So I've come here for brunch multiple times. And been blown away. I've come here for dinner a couple times. And been blown away (by their appetizers - deviled eggs are delicious! - their entrees, and their desserts!) I know I've had their oysters with a buddy who is more seafood inclined, and he was a fan (which means more than my "douse that shit in hot sauce and chug alcohol with it" approach).So...åÊthey're good. Really good. Service can be spotty sometimes - I felt a few times like I had to practically grab the server to get their attention for one more drink or to put in an order (but that hasn't been every time).And I still haven't had their burger!

Super busy place. Crowded and loud. Oh but the food! This is the reason this restaurant is desired. We had a reservation but had to wait for 20 mins. We were seated in the back, Gaby was our server. We started with the jalapeÌ±o spoon corn bread. Our entrees were fried chicken, shrimp and grits and scallops. The fried chicken was accompanied by a homemade cinnamon bun.  Yum! The portions are generous but not obnoxious. Fresh, tasty dishes. This is not a place for a romantic dinner, frankly it's too busy and too loud. It's frenetic at times, bit this is part of the fun and experience. I would highly recommend this restaurant.

We got lucky here! Came to The Pearl in time for their happy hour where menu items and cocktails were half off.Despite the great discount, the service was absolutely wonderful. I highly recommend the Pub burger as it's packed full of flavor and really is fresh ground. There's also some nice touches to this place from the nice decor to the bills being presented in an old book. Definitely check it out and go during happy hour if you can!

Four stars and two thumbs up for The Pearl - by far my favorite of the Cameron Mitchell spots I've tried. One glance at the menu with its creative, upscale spin on southern comfort food classics, and I was sold.I've dined several times with friends and have never left disappointed or hungry. The jalapeÌ±o corn spoon bread is my favorite of the starters I've tried - it's served sizzling in cast iron with creamy whipped butter dollops sitting and melting over the top (there's honey too). It melts in your mouth and hits all the right notes of salt, sweet, and spice. I've tried the clam chowder too but found it underwhelming with far too few discernible hunks of clam to be worth the price. Good flavor though.For my entree, every time I've dined, I've gone with the shrimp & grits. The Gouda grits have always been spot on - perfectly creamy and well-seasoned. The poblano pepper lends a mild heat and great smokiness to the dish, a welcome addition to this classic southern staple. It's my absolute favorite dish to order wherever I can find it, so I consider myself a bit of an expert when it comes to shrimp & grits, and The Pearl's version does not disappoint. Kielbasa is not my favorite, but it works well with the poblano and cheesiness of the grits. I'm yet to receive subpar shrimp - they've been plump and cooked well each time.The Pearl has a beautiful and stylish interior. At night, it's positively dazzling. Service is just fine, and the experience is always satisfactory or better! It's a reliable Short North star!

This may become one of my favorite happy hour spots in the Short North, and it may be my favorite Cameron Mitchell restaurant. It's an oyster bar, and it's 110% that and everything else it wants to be.The vibe is NYC/San Fran young, hip oyster bar - the lighting, the industrial/warehouse decor, the separation of the various seating areas - all matched with appropriately loud techno-remixed pop music. My kind of vibe for happy hour.Service was good, well-timed for enjoyment of drinks, appetizer(s), and entree. The happy hour prices and menu are crazy-good, and includes cocktails, wine, beer, starters, appetizers, AND sandwiches. That's half-off the food, you all. Including the charcuterie board ($24 full-price).Our meal was a three beers, a board (because yes, please), jalapeno spoon bread (on the house since they missed it on the order), a Cuban sandwich and their fried chicken. I know, I'm getting oysters next time.The charcuterie board was a selection of meats and spreads, plus a giant pile of the house-made pickles. Would order again for happy hour. The spoon bread was exactly that, served with butter and honey. Good, but had I realized the fried chicken came with a cinnamon roll, I'd have skipped it. Cuban was awesome-awesome the next day for lunch - no need to even reheat. Bursting with flavor, etc. The side of black beans was a keeper, too. The spouse had the fried chicken and damn, that is some GOOD fried chicken. Plus a cinnamon roll. And green bean casserole. HECK YEAH.Sadly, dessert was a no-go. I took all but three bites of my sandwich home with me. Regrets, I have them. Will rectify on the next visit.ANYWAY. Check = $53 for the whole shebang. Three drinks, one app, two entrees. [P.S. - Be sure to tip your wait staff on stated menu prices. They do the same amount of work during happy hour.] Great all-around experience.

I never plan on ending up at The Pearl, but often do, mostly for the fresh seafood and quality cooking.I should probably plan to visit The Pearl in advance, but I don't. So in the 3-4 times that I've eaten there, I've always ended up at the bar. Typically, I love the bar -- easy access to the second most important component of a meal. I've also always wondered why more people don't eat at The Pearl's bar and found out the hard way why they don't.What subtracts from any bar's appeal (and why people will choose not to eat at one) is a bar staff that often neglects and acts more important than its customers, and that's consistently what you'll find at The Pearl.The Pearl's bar is like a boat's 'brig' (cell), a punishment for guests who haven't made a reservation. Its head bartender is the warden. Empty drinks often sit without refills, which are not necessarily offered. Rather, refills require your plea. Want a water? Good luck. It doesn't matter if you're having a single beer or a full $200 meal for two -- you'll have to negotiate and conjure excuses to get one. Not acceptable at these prices: water should be served standard with no customer effort required.Beyond that, and despite the incredibly hackneyed decor and overplayed 'gastropub' theme, the food at The Pearl is often quite good. Fresh oysters from across the country offer great variety of size, flavor and texture, though the cleaning of each leaves something to be desired -- you'll frequently find yourself picking pieces of sand and shell from your mouth, a minor criticism and small price to pay for a rare Columbus commodity. Seafood entree specials offer balanced cooking and refreshing restraint of technique. I've had better seafood dishes at The Pearl than at any other seafood restaurant in Columbus.In short, if you want great seafood in Columbus, plan ahead and book at table at The Pearl. If you don't and still end up there, I'll save you a seat at the bar along with the other castaways, where you can fend for yourself.

A great gastropub type place! First off get here soon enough to just take in the vibe... laid back true all wood bar with that pub feel... Excellent.Have a drink... lots of specialty beers on tap or in bottles. I recommend the porter or the x2 milk stout! Fabulous Rich dark beers that you almost have to chew to get down... yummmmm!Then be sure to try their tots and their bacon wrapped dates... sinful...just completely sinful! (Don't fall for the bucket of pickles line... it is really no more then a saucer of bread and butter chunks) I moved from this to the chorizo dusted clam chowder... I love clam chowder.. I mean as far as soups go this was manna from heaven. It was spicy, filled with clams and in a buttery cream base. Divine!For my main course I had the Cuban sandwich. The bread was a bit hard and cut up my mouth some... but the flavor was pure pleasure. Pain and pleasure... ... what a sandwich!!my friends had the shark and the shrimp and grits... there was nothing left on their plates.For desert we had the Boston Cream Pie... it fell way short of the rest of the food... not at all what I expected after eating everything else.However the server was awesome! The meal was sublime (cut out the desert) and drinks were rich! The place was cool, packed with an eclectic crowd, clean and definitely a spot I would go to again!

This place came highly recommended to me since it's hard to find good oysters inland. My wife loves them and I took her here for her birthday. Prices were high but reasonable. We came for happy hour because it's half off starters, sandwiches and sides. Some drinks were also included but not all so make to ask! Our waiter was Charlie and he was very good and good looking! The staff all looked to the 9's and great atmosphere here for date night or grabbing quick drink. Great decor and plenty of bathrooms!Location is prime and parking structure was not that hard to find with only having to pay $5. Since it was her birthday, they even gave her complimentary dessert which of course she LOVED.  Only reason I docked them was that I ordered a steak medium rare and it was a lot more rare than I prefer so I ended up taking it home and cooking it more. The only minus was how salty it was.

As a fresh seafood fanatic, this is one of my go to places in Columbus.  The place has one of the freshest oyster selections I have experienced in Ohio.  If you love fresh oysters, this is the place to go.  Their mains and sides are also very good.  The restaurant itself is smack dab in the middle of the short north district.  There is convenient valet parking right on front for 8 dollars.  As this restaurant typically takes a bit to get a seat, there are great options on the street to get a drink while waiting (just hold off on the jenni's ice cream till after dinner!).The restaurant was kind enough give us an earlier reservation time as we arrived a bit early and we ended up getting seated close to the time provided.  The environment was great inside, however, was a bit close to the kitchen door.As noted before, the oysters were spectacular.  Recommendation would be the East cost Delaware bay oysters - great flavor and definitely fresh.  We also ordered the west coast, but those did not seem as fresh as the east coast option.Ordered the deviled eggs and bacon wrapped dates as well - both were great and would recommend as a small appetizer to share.  We also ordered the teriyaki octopus- it was above average and could have used a bit more crispness.For mains, we ordered a mix of the Great Lakes fried perch, fried chicken platter, braised short rib, and the hanger steak.  The winner is short rib by far - it was very tender and had great flavor.   Great pairing with the appetizers.  Fried chicken and the fried perch was average.  Hangar steak was cooked well, but slightly too salty.Wrapped up the meal with the recommended pie - it was fabulous and worthy of the praise.  Scoop of ice cream on top would have been perfect!Only negative I have is was the wait time.  It took 30-40 minutes to bring the appetizer and then another 30 or so to bring the main entrees.  When we ordered additional oysters, it did not arrive till after the meal.  Note that the restaurant did give us the oysters on the house which was much appreciated.All in all - great seafood establishment in Columbus short north.  I will be back!

We come to Columbus once a year for a Labor Day getaway and we have been coming to The Pearl since it first opened. When it first opened we had just incredible service and the oysters were very exotic, and it seemed less frantic and less like a chain.Now, the food is still excellent, but the oysters seem like more of an after thought and the wait staff is just ok. It seems just a hair overcrowded because they put the tables so close to each other. I requested a booth in the bar when I made my reservation, but did not get it. I was willing to wait but they sat us in an area that is overcrowded.Our waiter was just ok. He didn't know what the oysters were, and then the person who delivered the oysters to our table named the oysters to us wrong. Then, the waiter came back and said "he don't know what he's talking about".It's just too expensive for people to usher you in and out without exceptional care on where you sit, how they approach you and the service they present. I wish it was the Pearl of old.

How can one place have SO many amazing choices?! Wine, starters, snacks, dessert: all of it was amazing!They have a great wine selection - I'm not a connoisseur of wine by any means, so my friend picked us out a bottle and the menu seemed to have an extensive list of choices!For starters and snacks, we ordered quite a few things. My coworker ordered the lamb meatballs and was raving about how good they were! We all split the jalapeÌ±o corn bread and it was AMAZING! The honey and butter they give you on the side truly top it off. The deviled eggs come out on a crazy chicken weight scale (I know I sound weird but seriously it's a scale thing!) that make the presentation so awesome. The deviled eggs themselves were full of flavor and a great addition to our starters.For my entree, I had the hangar steak. Honestly, I wasn't that thrilled with it. I'm not too big into the Kimchee fried rice either. But the meat was tender! I don't think the restaurant is at fault here; I just think my flavor palette leans towards more traditional American food, and this dish had an international spin to it!The brown sugar butter pie for dessert is incredible. It melts in your mouth and is to die for! I think I'll be dreaming about it tonight! Overall, I love this place and will be back. And next time I intend to try the fried chicken that my friend said was awesome!

The good:  Food was really good! Enjoyed food and drinks. Location is great. Had no trouble parking. Not so good: Wasn't impressed with the wait staff. They were just ok. There should be a little more light for folks that have trouble reading. Even with reservations, we ended up will a really small table. We ordered the seafood tower and it barely fit our table. A bit uncomfortable. I would go again for the food.

We came with our daughter and son in law who had been before so we already expected the food to be good. Well we left our name and ph# however the hostess failed to call us because when we decided to check back in we were seated immediately we were told we would have a hour wait so weDecided to walk to kill time on such a beautiful sunny day why not . So the hostess needs to do her job better next time, and actually callIf that's what she tell you she's going to do . Had she called us sooner we probably would have had more than dessert.  The dessert was good loved our pies and appetizer. HOSTESS do a better job next time unless you didn't want our business . otherwise  because of her 3 stars instead of 4

One of my favorite restaurants in Columbus. My mother and I used to come here twice a month for dinner. They have great snacks. Their tater tots, fries, and deviled eggs are a few of my favorites. The cornbread is amazing. I order it every time I go. I have not had anything on he menu I haven't liked. I'm not a fan of oysters but, their fried oysters are the only time I eat them.

A really cool gastropub in the Short North. Great for brunch on the weekend or for dinner, I've never had a bad meal here. This most recent time, I decided to try the fish and chips, and I was not disappointed! One of the best fish and chips I've had in Columbus. They have a great drink menu too, with lots of their own cocktail creations.

I had an excellent happy hour experience with about 10 work friends. The reservation was easy, the service was excellent, and the happy hour menu was extensive. The HH menu was also great on pricing. A special shout out to our server, Chris, who knew his beers and made easy conversation before the rest of my friends got thereThe food and drinks were outstanding. I need to come here more often.

Ugggh, the best. I mean the oysters are fresh and they have an amazing variety for being landlocked. Their appetizers are ammmmmaaaaazing. And their happy hour is really ridiculously priced. Their mixed drinks are a little on the meh side, but it's my absolute favorite restaurant for food in town. Plus they have brown sugar pie that isn't quite as good as my Geandmother's but the closest I've come to hers.

I went to The Pearl for the first time last weekend with a bunch of friends for brunch. It was a game day, so the restaurant was pretty packed. My group had a reservation and because one table was taking super long to leave, it took a while to get us seated. The employees at The Pearl were quite apologetic and accommodating about the whole thing, which was nice. The general ambience of The Pearl is...interesting. There's a lot of mason jar type stuff going on, which always makes me raise my eyebrows a little bit. And they bring out receipts in books, which seems like a possible recipe for disaster to me (and certainly some of the stuff people had written/drawn in some of the books was as sophomoric as you might expect). Nevertheless, the experience was pretty good overall. I had the short rib poutine for my meal, and it was delicious. My only quibble would be on the low amount of short rib provided (especially since that was the tastiest part). Our server was very pleasant and always kept my cup of coffee full, which is something I always appreciate.

The Pearl has very good food. My boyfriend and I got the hanger steak, which was delicious. However, i reheated my leftovers and found some kind of metal piece in it. Not happy!Also, the server we had was very inattentive. Took 20 minutes to get water, boyfriends food was cold and server never came over to ask if it was okay. We went on our anniversary and was very disappointed. Probably wont be back. Other Cameron Mitchell restaurants like Marcellas and Molly Woos are much MUCH better service.

Great food and ambiance! I sat at the bar on a Tuesday evening while staying in Columbus on business. Ordered the Arctic Char which could have used a bit more roasted cauliflower in my opinion but still a well balanced delicious menu item! I would go back with clients or dinner with my wife for the ambiance alone! The other bar patrons seemed to really be enjoying the handcrafted unique cocktails, unfortunately I didn't feel up to getting a drink(was feeling like passing out at the bar after my busy travel schedule that week) but will be back to try several the next time I find myself in Columbus.

My friend and I got here around 7:15 on a Saturday and lucky enough to find seats at the bar (make a reservation!) It took a bit to get acknowledged but as soon as we did, we got an apology and the service from there on our was great! Our server was friendly and checked on us multiple times. We ordered the deviled eggs to share and they were delicious and had a fun presentation. She got the skirt steak with the egg and kimchi and I got baked clams and fries on the side. Our food was delicious and we ate everything. I've also been here before and gotten the steak. This place is a must try! Both times I enjoyed the food and service.

Food was good but experience/service could have been better. I went on a Sunday evening so it was not too busy and ordered the shellfish tower which includes oysters, clams, shrimp, and crab for $90. The waiter came back saying the shrimp was not available but it could be substituted with oysters or crab. Although not the most ideal I settled with more crab. Then when the appetizers came up the waiter told us the kitchen had mixed up and the shrimp was available, which got me excited. Then when our tower came, the waiter told us the kitchen counted wrong and there was actually no shrimp for our tower but they put in more crab instead. This back and forth was at best a miscommunication and at worst a lack of organization skills... how hard is it to figure out how many shrimp are available and if there's enough for a table?? For a higher end place I found that annoying. On a super busy night it may be more understandable but it was fairly empty when we arrived. The waiter was probably just passing messages from the kitchen, but somewhere along the way they screwed up multiple times. Although the oysters were great and corn bread was wonderful, the back and forth really didn't allow for the experience to be the best it could be.

I have changed my mind.Skeptical about the oysters after the first experience but I have returned a few times since and think the oysters are pretty good! They are $2 each raw, which I would definitely recommend, although please also try the baked ones which come in a little broth and a piece of baguette! Half off the snacks, sandwiches, starters, cocktails, and draft beers....so I'm definitely visiting more often!
If your wife turns you down go get a Pub burger with tater tots.... it might just be better.
Love love love this place. Great atmosphere, really cool decor. Amazing menu with twists on all the American favorites. I don't think you can go wrong with anything you order!

I'm feeling a little like a broken record here....... why can they not have places like this in Augusta? Le sigh. Oh well, I will be back in Columbus and hope to come back here to try more and for their happy hour at some point. Long story short, my sister and I were doing a play on words to celebrate every anniversary for my parents up to their 40th. This was the place we chose for their 30th anniversary (the gift is a pearl for those who have no idea what I'm talking about). My sister had been here in the past and knew that she wanted everyone to try the Devils on Horseback (bacon-wrapped dates), Peel & Eat Shrimp and Chicken & Waffles. We were going to do oysters but decided against. Don't worry......we will be back to try them. I was surprised at how much I liked the Devils on Horseback seeing as I'm not a fan of dates and am not in LOVE with bacon. I would absolutely order those again. The blueberry compote that was served with the Chicken & Waffles was droolworthy. The Peel & Eat Shrimp were HUGE and the cocktail sauce served with them hit the spot. We all ordered drinks too and loved them. I appreciated the way the Bloody Mary was served because I've never seen it served that way and I've ordered them in several places. They had a little skewer of goodies on it, but also served with a 4 oz Miller High Life. I tried the Ramos Gin Fizz and that may be my new favorite drink. It was perfect. I loved the decor in the place, as well. Also, mouthwash in the bathroom? Who would have ever thought of that? I love it.

If you want fresh oysters this is the place! They have very fresh oysters from a few different locations in the U.S. so it can vary where your oysters come from. The servers are very knowledgeable about the differences in the oysters so just ask! I prefer them raw but they have baked as well!The bloody Mary's are pretty good, they will also bring you a little miller lite with it too! The other drinks are good, balance of alcohol to mixer are on point.Try the Devils on horseback. Goodness. They are tasty. The cornbread was very good as well. Get the braised short rib too, tender and juicy and everything you want from a short rib.The atmosphere is super cool and I love the look of this restaurant. It's like the 20s came back and they give you your check in an actual book.
The service and food is always excellent. Great Happy Hour 1/2 off apps. The selection of oysters is awesome.

Great fish and chips! The portion was big and the fish was tender. The tartar sauce had great flavor and the coleslaw was still crunchy. And $17 seemed like a reasonable price. The place has a really nice atmosphere with dim lighting although it does feel a tad crowded. Luckily we had a seat against the wall. The cocktail menu is pretty expansive and all are about $10. I had a delicious margarita that was made with fresh ingredients and not a syrupu

Food was excellent.  Server (Brady) was awesome - granted every off the wall request we had with a smile. he made the experience incredible for my 81 year old mother in law.  Will definitely be back next time we are in Columbus.

I have very mixed feelings about The Pearl. The concept is wonderful- Cameron Mitchell really thought this one through. It's a great mix of Southern cooking and the oysters that so many (fancy) people adore. That's great. But the execution of some of these foods comes off as odd, and in Columbus, I'm not sure it's really what people are looking for.SIDE NOTE: the happy hour is amazing because things cost literally half of their normal price. If that was the case all the time, then 5 stars! But currently it's only 4-6 M-F.I have been to the Pearl for both dinner and brunch, but I was there for brunch most recently so I'm going to comment on that. I will start by saying our server was great and very prompt in coming back to the table to check on us, so no complaints there. But the drink prices alone for brunch are $10-$12, entrees are $12-$25, and they don't serve bread or anything before the meal, so my starving self ordered some pancakes to start things off too, which was $6 each split between 2 people. Now, I would be less harsh about these prices if the portion sizes were better, but I personally ate 1.5 meals at brunch and I wasn't particularly stuffed. For my entree, I ordered the eggs and grits, and I was not disappointed with the flavor. Rich, cheesy grits with poached eggs and green onions/celery on top. It was also strangely served with these tiny pieces of cornbread, and a container of molasses, I guess for dipping the cornbread? I didn't really understand that part. A friend ordered the huevos rancheros and it was maybe 8 oz. of food plus a tortilla. Not really enough food, or worth $16. They also offer a short rib poutine which had amazing flavor, complete with a fried egg on top, but it was about $15 for a single serving of fries coated in gravy with an egg. I'm not seeing the value for the cost. Also it is very dark inside the restaurant, especially if you're near the back, so it's not the best place to enjoy a bright and airy mid-day brunch. Overall, it is a good concept, and if you're willing to spend a bunch of money then it can be a good experience, but it is not my favorite brunch spot in the Short North.

One of my favorite brunch spots!! I always seem to get the same thing - short rib poutine. The egg on top of all the gooeyness really makes it. I also had a grapefruit mimosa. It had that tartness I love in all grapefruit drinks. Go early or make reservations on the weekend. It does get crowded very quickly.
I absolutely love this place!! The ambiance is amazing. Everyone is so kind when I come in and the food is always delicious!!

Was here on a business trip, my first time visiting Ohio. This restaurant was across from myHotel. We asked for a both and they accommodated us.Our server WA Nick, he made it a great experience for us. He was attentive, had great suggestions, and made sure our drinks were always full and we weren't wanting or needing anything. We had to deviled eggs, bacon wrapped dates, the spinach salad, and the short ribs. My associates had the Clam chowder, hanger steak, and the smoked salmon appetizer. The deviled eggs were awesome, as were the bacon wrapped dates. You could really taste the mustard in the eggs and the presentation was fun. The short ribs were really good, not great by really good. I think they could have used a bit more sauce but I ate the whole thing anyway. I was starving!! I had a glass of wine, my dinner dates had Moscow Mules which they said were amazing. For dessert we were treated to the crack pie, not sure if that's the name but if it's not it should be. We were all so happy with everything. DefinitelyCheck this place out and ask to be seated with Nick!! He is amazing and made this such an awesome experience.

Booked reservations for a Sunday Brunch at The Pearl, never been there but have passed it a number of times on High St...we got there and had to wait, even though we had a reservation....sat down and immediately  noticed the cool decor of the restaurant, open spacious, lots of rustic brick and wood...just a cool looking place...ordered parmesan baked clams and nawlins oysters, since I love seafood so much and can't find many great seafood options in Ohio....Clams and Oysters came out and looked pretty, both appetizers were very good, i liked the nawlins oysters a little better, the briny moisture and juice from the oysters mixed with new orleans style seasoning was perfect and just enough kick and seasoning to take it over the top...the parmesan baked oysters were also delicious, they were salty a bit, but again, I would order them again, because they were pretty damn good...oh yeah, order extra bread with the oysters/clams so you can sop up the wonderful juices and flavors left over from the bake!! you won't be sorry....I ordered the short rib putine, all I can say is wow!! the order came out and it was a lovely sunny side up egg, over fries and chunks of short rib beef and a wonderful gravy .....gravy, fries, and a runny egg, does it get any better than that!!! I attacked my dish and if I could have licked the plate I would have, but my mom taught me to have manners in public  : )) Seriously, I can't say enough about the Sunday Brunch at The Pearl, wonderful and over the top, great place to go for happy hours with that special person or just casual date night....get to The Pearl and enjoy folks!!

I went there to treat my roomie for her bday.  Can't remember exactly what I ordered, just remember the feeling of the food. It tasted like the crab bowel if you have ever tried the crab bowel in Boston. But not that good as in Boston. The oysters were just fine, not surprised too much.

Wonderful place! Went here last night and I was blown away! Every staff member was polite, engaging and seemed happy to be there! The guy (Lucas) at the oyster bar was great conversation and service, as well as our waiter Eric who anticipated every request! The oysters on the half shell were fresh as can be! We got the Shrimp and Grits + the Great Lakes fish and chips, and wow! Didn't know shrimp and grits could be so tasty!Highly recommend this for any occasion! This place is a must when in Columbus. I will definitely be returning soon!!!

This is my husband and I's "special spot". We love the food and drinks, and the happy hour prices cannot be beat. I like the low key atmosphere and the comfortable decor. We also get great service, and well, we just love The Pearl. :)I recommend the small plate salmon, it is a huge portion, and during happy hour, it is half off.

In a word, delish.  So, so good!  I've been here a few times before but forgot how tasty everything is!  My fiancÌ© went here Saturday night as an extension to my birthday celebration.  It was 65 degrees in February, so they were packed...they did have a few seats at the little oyster bar that was first come, first serve, so we went for it.  To start we had he jalapeÌ±o honey corn bread=AMAZEBALLS, deviled eggs=very good!I always get the beet salad (excellent, but pretty small for $11.00) and my boo had the fish and chips.  He said it was very good, but the fries were a tad soggy for his liking.  I tried his coleslaw and didn't care for it.  The tartar sauce was ridiculously good!!  The service was just ok...but they were pretty busy!  She tried to charge me for an ice tea that I had ordered but it never came, so I didn't ask again.  Definitely a fan...I wanna go back for HH!

Divine, simply divine. After a long, hot Friday dilly dallying about Columbus, my friend and I strolled into here for dinner after seeing the great reviews. Everything at The Pearl is excellent. We drank, we ate, and we were oh so very merry!First of all, they have some kickass bloody Mary's. Like...wow. And they serve it with salami, a pickle, an olive, and...Miller High Life. We shared the charcuterie platter and let me tell you, as two Jews from New York, the liver was EXCELLENT. We also had the peel and eat gulf shrimp, and my friend is originally from the south so she's very critical of her shellfish, and she said these shrimp were awesome. For the entree we decided to change it up a bit so we shared the ricotta dumplings. Wow, just wow.Everything is great, even our server was amazing (shoutout to Eric!). Though they seated us instantly, make a reservation, this place is a hotspot.

I recently chose The Pearl for a group (6 people) work dinner and I was very underwhelmed. It was a cold Tuesday evening in January, and despite the fact that we had reservations, we still had to wait 20 minutes for our table, beyond the reservation time. One of our party ordered salmon and it was horribly undercooked, so she sent it back. When they brought it out a second time, it was equally as raw! When she sent it back a second time the server gave her a little attitude and said "Well did you want this cooked well done? Salmon is served medium rare." I order salmon at restaurants all the time and I have never been served salmon as raw as it was on her plate. They did get her meal right the 3rd time, but by the time they brought the 3rd plate out, the rest of us were finished eating. I had ordered a different salmon dish and was just counting my lucky stars that my fish was thoroughly cooked when I hit the middle and it was more undercooked than I'm used to, so I didn't finish my meal. Due to the seating delay and the 2 salmon plates we sent back, our dinner lasted much later than anticipated. I'm disappointed because I've always heard great things about The Pearl and I LOVE seafood. I doubt I'll return.
This was an amazing American restaurant. We did not have any seafood, but no doubt it is as good as what we had. I definitely would come back for dinner or recommend this restaurant.

On weekends (and maybe other days) it's good to make reservations ahead of time. Everything here was great. We started with the Devils on Horseback and Tater Tots. I really don't know what was inside the DoH, but it was bacon wrapped goodness. The tater tots were a creamy mashed potato-like mixture with a thin but crisp outer shell like a tater tot. They were simply awesome and came with a dipping sauce. The cocktails are real cocktails, not just a mixture of ingredients. They taste as they're described and are very good/interesting combinations. I had the Shrimp & Grits. It's a thinner type of red sauce and was very good. Other dishes looked equally as good. Happy hour has half priced appetizers and drinks. Well worth the early arrival. The atmosphere is unique and has an open kitchen.  I'll definitely be back.

Our first visit to this restaurant. Went on a Thu evening and the place was hopping. Good thing we made reservations and were taken to our table immediately. The server was extremely polite and professional. The ambience is modern and nice. It was loud but not enough to impair a conversation. Their wine selection is quite good. My wife ordered a merlot and I got their  house Cabernet, both were  pretty decent. For appetizers we had a half dozen oysters, most of them were very good (not top restaurant east coast good, but  good nonetheless). The clam chowder was surprisingly delicious, and this is from someone who recently came returned from a trip to Boston. The spinach salad was only so so. I'd recommend against ordering it. Their market special of the day was a fresh walleye, which was prepared very well. The one omission was that they did not include bread with the meal. We were told that the restaurant does not offer complimentary bread so we ordered a baguette, which was okay. All in all a nice evening. I'd probably come back to try their other offerings.

I love going to the Pearl when I have a craving for oysters! I actually got a chance to check it out during happy hour which they have an excellent selection of! I couldn't sit at my usual spot and couldn't have the same waiter (love him and his energy and attitude but i dont know his name.. he is in the back area!) so my friend and i sat at the oyster bar. If you are sensitive to smell I don't recommend sitting there because the smell of oysters will get to you. I was fine but my friend did mention it a few times. Ordered the rockpoint, blue point, and the chesapeake oysters! I think the rock point is my favorite. Very smooth and not too salty. The brie grilled cheese sandwich is good but maybe too cheesy for you so the arugula salad really balanced it out. My friend got the board of cheese and meats and she enjoyed it thoroughly. Although she mentioned the pickles almost masked the flavor of everything else. The beets salad was so good, although it might have been better if the veggies were a bit colder. Tasted lukewarm and the avocado were brown. The waiters were all over the place so we had to deal with three waiters to get things in or our checks. Water wasnt refilled as fast either. That oyster bar section was pretty ... inconvenient.

Long term patron of Pearl.  After the waiter highly recommended a poached egg breakfast special he couldn't pronounce(chilaquiles), we decided to go with his recommendation. He came back with the special with poached eggs hard cooked and cold. After politely asking him to return the special and if possible bring us freshly poached eggs, the waiter walked away from us mid-sentence. Have you ever experienced something so incredibly humiliating at a restaurant?  At any rate, we spoke to the manager, who to his credit, offered his apologies and to comp us for our meal.  The experience was so bizarre and upsetting we decided to leave and, of course, never to come back. Oh, Pearl - you break our hearts... Perhaps googling "how to poach an egg" for the kitchen staff and googling "how to politely speak to a customer" for the waiting staff would be in order.

Great beer list. Good food, and the company I had while dining here might have made it worth it.  Met some cousins I hadn't seen in a few years here, while I was in town.The menu seemed pretty standard American, but spotlighted some local flavors and flare. Rustic modern ambience. Happy service. But, none of the food really stood out to me - everything we had - and we had a lot, was shared and enjoyable, but after heading home, I can't really think of anything that I would go back to this restaurant for.That's not to say I would not return - I absolutely would. But I wouldn't make the trip to Columbus for this restaurant alone.

Wow, this was the best meal I've had in a long time.  I had the hanger steak, which was juicy and tender on a flavorful bed of fried rice and topped with a runny fried egg.  I've never had this particular combination before, but it was wonderful.  Good portion size too.  My wife had the short rib and horseradish mashed potatoes, which was also fantastic.  While these are close to $30, which is more than I'd probably spend on the typical night out, these were not typical meals.  Delicious food, and lots of it.  Well worth the cost.Nice drink menu.  There are a number of cocktails that sound great.  The Manhattan was one of the better Manhattans I've had in awhile.  The Peanut Butter and Pearl Jam was surprisingly good.  There's also a strong beer list featuring quite a few Belgian selections.Attentive, friendly service.  Nice atmosphere.  It was busy, but didn't feel crowded or too loud.  Beautiful, elegant space.Highly recommended.
Amazing dinner and drinks.  Phenomenal staff.  I live in the south, but their fried chicken is the best I have ever had.  Highly recommend.

LOVED my experience at the Pearl. My sister and I came to dinner here when we were in town for the holidays. We sat at the bar since we came a little early and had some wonderful cocktails. My sister got moscow mules and I ordered gin based drinks which were fantastic!My sister had a couple friends working that night and they went above and beyond to make sure that we had an amazing first experience at the Pearl. We both got the hanger steak, which was delicious and cooked perfectly.You definitely need a reservation for a weekend dinner here, but there is open bar seating if you can snag a seat or two. I loved the ambiance, the music, and the vibe of the restaurant. The deviled eggs were also a hit, along with the cornbread.I think the pricing was also appropriate as well for the service and portions. Definitely a must go if you're in the short north!

After three cancelled reservations (due to work conflicts) we FINALLY made it to dinner at the Pearl. It was good but may be slightly over hyped...First and foremost the service was top notch! Our waiter (Andrew) was a great host and showed a lot of patience with our very indecisive table. Appetizers - Octopus and Corn bread. believe the hype on the corn bread! the octopus, not so much...For dinner - we ALL four got the Artic Char. I asked for regular mashed potatoes and feel that was the perfect complement to the buttery fish. Dessert - The best part of the meal! We had the seasonal pie and Boston Cream PieI hear great things about their happy hour and would like to see if it is a better bang for your buck!

I can't say enough good things about this place. The menu changes just enough to be relevant with the season but keep old favorites around. The shrimp and grits and roasted chicken are not to be missed. Drinks are mixed well and different from the usual fair. Try the duke of pearl! The staff is always friendly, and informed on the menu. Trust their suggestions! The ambience is great. Perfect for a date night. They also use OpenTable so even on a busy weekend you can guarantee your spot.

In Columbus, this is a great spot for Oysters and Thursday is happy hour with 1/2 off specials. A very cool place to be and enjoy a good meal. If you are a chowder fan(spelled Chowda were I am from), it is outstanding. Plenty of clams and just a great recipe. My server Hanna really made the experience special and will definitely be back for sure the next time I am in town. A must visit

I went here with recommendation since I was in Columbus, OH for conference at Ohio State University. The restaurant was packed. They said there is about a hour and half wait. I should have made reservation. But they said we can sit by the bar and have full meal. So we decided to do that. We had shimp and grits & hanger steak with eggs. Menu was somewhat limited.  My friend enjoyed steak with eggs. I had a bite of that meat was very nicely cooked. My shrimp with Grits was okay, but grits did not have much taste to it. I took brown sugar pie with cream to take back. That pie was awesome, it was extremely tasty. I would recommend it. If I am in the town again, I would go back there. They did not gave any bread or anything to start with. What you order is what you get.

The Pearl was a perfect start to a nice, long-weekend, semi-staycation.  Ever been to a place with amazing, gourmet food, high-end beer and wine, perfect service, AND a casual atmosphere where you could rock a sweatshirt and chucks?  This is one of those places.  I can't even begin to list all the stuff the three of us had to eat...but it was all perfect.

Came here for the happy hour. Prices were fair for the oysters and the drinks. $5 moscow mules! Select appetizers were also half off during this time. The charcuterie plate was an interesting experience. Not a fan of their caviar mustard, but it was cool to try so many different meats and spreads. Not worth it if it was not happy hour. I am happy with the $2 oysters during happy hour. That was the highlight of the meal as they were fresh and tasty. This place is quite romantic with the lighting and atmosphere and they have funny dog paintings hung up in the restrooms. Overall a little pricey and worth a visit during happy hour for the oysters!

I romanticize The Pearl. I tell all my friends it's my favorite brunch spot. Then, when I finally do get there, I remember, I just really love their Bloody Mary's!! C'mon they come with a mini bottle of Miller high life. The Devils on horseback: bacon wrapped dates with a garlic, cilantro drizzle. Yum!! I had the salmon which is a starter but, a huge portion of perfectly poached salmon with a caper lemon sauce and one perfect deviled egg. I love it!The hanger steak would be so much better if it was served with something other than ginger, soy- ish rice. It does have great flavor, just too much, it overpowers the dish and you really can't enjoy the steak.Everything is plated, arranged and served to please, not just the taste buds, but the eyes.

I love this place. Great atmosphere and great food.  The drinks come fast and you can get a seat at the bar if you wait in the right place. For starters they have the best deviled eggs and tater tots.  Do that.  You will be satisfied. I have got the hanger steak all 3 times and will get again. An Asian slant and a fried egg.  It is perfect if medium rare. This is a great place for you and that special someone to have dinner out in the short north.

Don't mess around.  Get the burger or the short ribs.  You won't be disappointed, especially if you have an appetite.  Good atmosphere and great place to cost in the summer.  Food is served fast even when crowded.

I've kind of been putting off writing this review because I wish my review was better than just 3 stars! I made a reservation for a Friday dinner here. The entrance was pretty crowded, but we were greeted and seated in 5 min. My date and I both ordered Moscow mule's, I wasn't crazy about mine - I think it tasted like 95% ginger beer. We went ahead and ordered our entire meal at once so we could just talk and relax. We ordered baked clams, ricotta dumplings, and the special of the night which was some sort of seafood Thai curry. Our food didn't take too long to come out - but our entrees came out before our baked clams :( our server swung by and apologized, letting us know that the baked clams would be on the house. The ricotta dumplings were good, but I wasn't a huge fan, and the portions were mediocre. The seafood Thai curry was spicy!! and we both liked it - but again, not a very good value (I think it was $30+). The star of the night was definitely the baked clams. Serving situation was kind of mixed - a lot of attention to random details - our candle went out and he came by to light it probably 30 seconds after... but not too much attention otherwise. Also when he came to deliver the check at the end of the night, he forgot to take the baked clams off... which felt kind of awkward and we were just preparing to pay for them... until he came back to pick up the credit card and remembered.  I have a big sweet tooth and since we were enjoying a nice night out we ordered the banana cream pie - ugh it was not very good, and definitely not worth the $6-7. We had a great time and a nice meal that i kind of wished I loved, but I'd say it was not worth the $$$. I'm not too interested in returning, but I'm sure my arm could be twisted for happy hour and baked clams/oysters.

The food isn't anything special. The oysters were ridiculously overpriced...about $2 an oyster. I got a truffle pasta, and the portions were small, especially for the price. Probably won't be back unless someone else is treating.

I have been here more times than I can count but I can say this place is not up to par for Cameron Mitchell.  For starters my son received undercooked fried chicken that was still bloody.  My husband ordered attic char and received salmon and our appetizer never came.  I am very disappointed especially since I have been here so many times and had a great experience.
