The wine was good but the heavy salt in the food really made the experience sub par and not meet the standards of what I will call one of the top restaurants in Columbus. Next time watch the salt and try to make the food top tier.

First time I went it was pretty good. Not the most amazing food ever but not disappointing. All of the tables are pretty close together so you don't get much privacy, but you kind of know that going into it. The decorations are awesome. Got the seafood tower the second time and it was very underwhelming. In hindsight I wish they'd tell you the price for the day (you feel awkward asking-$90 when we went if anyone is wondering) and let you know what all is on it. The crab salad was veryy mayonnaise-y with not much flavor. Also it had a gross black hair in it. Waitress offered a replacement crab salad to go but that is definitely not a to go leftover type food...didn't offer anything else, but we didn't make a huge stink of it. The oysters were mostly really good (and were last time as well) but some were pretty sandy. Mostly just grossed out by the raw clams. We wrongly assumed they would be steamed. There were like 13 of them and we both gagged after eating the first: they were so fishy and slimy. I felt pretty queasy later that night and had only choked down two. Hostesses not the friendliest but the servers have been very nice. Not super speedy, but I totally get that and don't mind at all when it is crowded. For the prices vs. what you get, I'd recommend Philco diner right down the street...so delicious every time we go.

Great restaurant! We went for brunch and loved everything! The atmosphere was on point, the drinks were great, and the food was all delicious! Good service too. Must-haves include the Bloody Mary, with included "beer back", and definitely the cinnamon roll to start--which rivaled my grandmother's recipe! Loved their version of eggs Benedict, the tavern Benny, and my husbands bananas foster French toast! Yum! The little touches in the bathrooms were cute too, like hairspray and mouthwash. Would definitely recommend!

We went to The pearl becasue of the ratings on Yelp and it was a Cameron Mitchell restaurant.  The hostess was cold and expressionless.  We asked for the warm spot in the restaurant because my elderly mom is very sensitive to the cold.  After ordering, there was a fierce cold breeze (it was 30 degrees outside).  Right down the hall from our table was  the back door where waiters traipsed in and out with the garbage.   There was also a scented candle in the hall so the smell permeated the air around us.  It only got worse.  My husband and I ordered shrimp and grits.  It was mediocre at best and the serving was small.  My dad ordered the short rib dinner.  He said it was pot roast in disguise and not very good at all.  Then a waiter propped open the back door.   We told our server.  he did move us.  So we ate dinner in our coats freezing and the food was mediocre.  We complained to the manager and she gave us a coupon for $50.  Our meal came to $100.  There is no way we are going back.  Fortunately the coupon is good for any Cameron Mitchell restaurant.  I hope the next one is better. Our waiter was nice though.

Fairly decent food but overly priced.  That is how I'd sum up my experience at The Pearl.My dinner date and I had booked a reservation for Valentine's Day.  I had been eagerly anticipating this restaurants' opening for months.  I am a raw oyster fanatic and while their oysters were tasty, they were way over priced at $3 each.  The average price for oysters in Columbus is probably $2.  I didn't feel that the oysters at The Pearl were any more fresh than other restaurants I've been to.  I also would have liked to see each variety of oyster labeled on the platter they are served on.  I ordered 3 different kinds of oysters, but wasn't told which was which when they were served.Happy Hour is Mon-Fri from 4-6 and consists of half off starters and drafts.  I tried the crispy fried cheese curds.  They were crispy on the outside, gooey and delicious on the inside and finished off with awesome fried bits of parsley sprinkled on top.  I also tried the Devils on Horseback which are chese stuffed dates wrapped in bacon.  I loved the balance of sweet and savory.  To wet the ol whistle, I ordered their Moscow Mule which was served in a copper mug as a mule should.  It was good, but nothing special.  I would have liked a stronger punch of ginger.My entree was probably the biggest disappointment of my experience.  I ordered the fish and chips.  At $16, I was expecting to taste something unique or at least a damn good fried fish.  It was ok, but lacked anything to make it memorable.  Our waitress was very attentive, but probably too attentive.  She literally came over to ask if we were ok every 3 minutes or less.  It kind of made it hard to enjoy my meal and my date's company when she was there every freaking minute.  I'd like to come back sometime and try the House smoked salmon or charcuterie board.

It was love at first sight. And then it was love (again) at first bite.The Pearl was a sensory overload for me because the space is equally as beautiful as the food is delicious. But I'll get into the details a little later...Picture it: The middle of January, and I wander over to Open Table to see if - by some slim chance - The Pearl was already accepting reservations. And the search results? 7pm on opening night!Fast forward to tonight. Most restaurant opening nights are honestly a mess. But that's part of the fun, right? I was totally expecting the worst and was just going to happily go along for the ride. But guess what? The Pearl's opening night wasn't a mess - not even a little bit! It wasn't perfect, but it was perfectly charming. I think "thoughtful" is the best way to describe everything at The Pearl. There isn't one detail left forgotten - whether it's the everything-from-scratch food, the beautiful-but-rustic ambiance, or the exceptional service. Here's a little more about each of those...The decor is exactly what I would do if I were building a house and had unlimited funds. Think: hardwood floors, rustic wooden tables, white-painted brick, glass accessories, and subway tiles. The serving plates were white, the silverware mis-matched, and mason jars for glasses. The bathrooms, although small, were showpieces of their own with dark wood and subway tiles in white, gray, and teal. Everything was beautiful without being fussy - just the way I like it.Before dinner, our table decided to order a bowl of bourbon apple punch. And it came out in a punch bowl. The crystal kind. Like Grandma had. It was totally adorable, and the punch was super tasty.The food was a delightful paradox: familiar, yet unexpected and down-home, yet up-scale. Here's what our table shared and a grade (just for fun):* Pork belly bau buns - A+* Devils on horseback (bacon-wrapped dates, stuffed with five cheese) - A* Fried cheese curds with gravy for dipping (like a less-messy poutine) - A-* Fried chicken, Southern-style greens, and a cinnamon bun - A+* Cuban sandwich (B-) with black bean soup (A) - B average* Grilled cheese with brie and pear jam - BThe fried chicken was my dish, and this is a pretty bold declaration: it's the best fried chicken in Columbus. If you're a fan of Maya's fried chicken truck, you'll love The Pearl's. The pieces were small, which is great because there's more crispies and you don't have to worry about the chicken not being cooked all the way through. The greens were the best I've had outside of my native Louisiana. And the cinnamon bun? To. Die. For.As for the service, Jesse was our server, and he couldn't have been better. I think he had first-night jitters, but who wouldn't? He was insanely attentive, and we were never left wanting a thing. A server who keeps my water glass constantly filled is A-okay in my book. Jesse really cared about our experience, and he frequently checked on us. This was top-notch service.I think The Pearl is what I always wanted Hubbard Grille to be. If you're like me and looking for a special night out that's still casual and fun, you're going to love The Pearl. This is totally going to be my new date-night spot. In fact, we already have reservations for Valentine's Day.

The decor and ambiance here is wonderful! I met up with some friends for dinner one night. Everything went pretty smoothly service wise besides the waitress forgot about my friend's cocktail, but she didn't charge her for it, which was thoughtful. We got the devils on horseback, jalapeno corn bread (forgot exactly what it was called), and the baked oysters for appetizers. The devils on horseback were good, but the portion was very small, and it was a bit too oily. The jalapeno corn bread was good, but I think it was lacking more jalapeno/spicy flavor. It mostly tasted like corn bread to me. And then the baked oysters nawlins style were super small and not very worth it. I don't think I'd get those again, but I'd want to try the raw oysters here some other time.My friends got the pub burger and arctic char while I got the hanger steak. The pub burger was pretty good, and the arctic char was decent too, but for the price, I don't know if the char was worth it. The hangar steak was good, but the kimchi fried rice/sauce was really REALLY salty. I had to move most of it away from the steak because I almost couldn't eat it. We didn't get any dessert since we were full, but I'll probably take a look at that next time. Nothing was bad, but nothing especially impressed me either after hearing the hype about this place. I would go back to try some other entrees though. The fried chicken looks tempting! Maybe even for brunch some time too!

I'm only ever eating at Cameron Mitchell restaurants from now on, always. We went on a Saturday afternoon for some drinks and oysters. We ended up ordering an actual meal because the apps were so good we felt like we had to try the entrees! They do a special brunch menu on weekends. Service: Never better. Our waiter was super sweet and really attentive. They make absolutely everything from scratch, he said, except the Heinz ketchup! The staff seem really proud of the restaurant and how special it is, and that is a really nice attitude to have and it makes the customers feel like their experience really is special and unique, like they've been let in on a fabulous secret. Drinks: Vodka tonic is the best I've ever had in my whole life, and I have these everywhere I go and on every continent I've been to. They make their own tonic water and its heavenly. It has kind of a sweet taste, so beware: its still strong! careful! Bloody Mary really was "the best in town". Actually I think its the best in several towns. I loved that it was kind of rustic (served in a mason jar), and the tomato juice (home-made) had a bit of pulp in it, which I loved. Perfect flavor and seasoning, and it was strong too! Food:Get oysters. We had the Nola style oysters which comes in a divine buttery sauce, so good we almost licked it off the plate.Delicious "Pub burger", cooked well (true medium), and bun was the best kind of bun.  The meat was also buttery and melt-in-your-mouth!  The cambozola cheese makes it taste a bit more fancy than the average pub burger. The HOMEMADE TOMATO JAM was so good. Also, the waiter was really accommodating. I casually mentioned we would share, and he had the kitchen cut the burger in half, and bring us separate plates with our own fries. It was such a nice touch, love the close attention to detail this place really has with everything.Also its worth the price. It is actually surprisingly inexpensive for the quality of food, drink, and service.

Went with a few friends for dinner on Friday night--not sure what the wait time would have been if we hadn't made a reservation earlier in the week as it looked pretty full. Overall, the ambiance was nice, but a little dark. Our booth/table was comfortable and it seemed like they were able to accommodate a few large groups in the section next to ours. We all ordered Moscow Mules, which were delicious. They muddle their own ginger, and you can definitely taste the difference. At $10 each, they were a little pricey but not expensive enough to keep us from ordering a second round. :) As a recent New Orleans transplant, I was excited to see baked oysters on the menu! There were only three in an order, but the broth was great, oysters were a little salty. I ordered the Pub Burger, which was excellent. The gf went with the fish and chips, which was good but normal. We split a piece of brown sugar pie for dessert, which was really freaking awesome. Extra points for fresh whipped cream. Our waiter was friendly, and clearly knowledgable about the menu. Why only four stars? -It was kind of noisy-For the price of the entrees ($15-30), I was surprised that we didn't get bread or some other pre-entree snacky. -Menu was pretty limited (maybe 8 entrees?). Things seemed consistently high quality, but were pretty specific. For example, the only pasta dish was ramen with a pork loin. No other seafood pasta options. I'd go back, but might try other places first.

The atmosphere is fun, and the good is wonderful!! Get the beet salad, seriously. I have never liked beets AT. ALL. and I actually crave this salad. I had a great bloody mary there, and have never had a bad entree. Plan ahead for parking...sometimes you have to walk a bit, but it's a nice walk..

The Pearl, in my opinion, is a restaurant for hipsters. If you like to go to a popular but overcrowded restaurant and overpay for overrated food while drinking out of a mason jar, this is your restaurant. We dined here this past Saturday (7/19/14) for the second time. The first time (I think around December 2013), we were underwhelmed. But we love Cameron Mitchell restaurants, so we had to give them a second try. Unfortunately, our second visit was even worse. Having been to every Cameron Mitchell restaurant in Columbus, I will not hesitate to say that the Pearl is easily his worst restaurant. Now let me be clear-- The Pearl isn't bad, per se. It's just nowhere near as good as everyone else on Yelp claims it to be. The food/service at the Pearl certainly doesn't justify the price premium that they charge. And all the other Cameron Mitchell restaurants are just better in all aspects. The restaurant itself is very, very crowded and very cramped. I suppose you might expect that from a restaurant in the Short North. The amount of space you get here is similar to Marcella's, even though you're paying like you're at Martini. Perhaps due to the crowd, the service here is hands down the worst out of all the Cameron Mitchell restaurants in town. We made a reservation with OpenTable and arrived 5 minutes early. When we tried to check in, the host muttered under his breath to the girl next to him, "I just gave away their table..." Thanks man. 15 minutes later and after being skipped by 3 other parties whose reserved tables the host apparently didn't give away, we were seated.The beer list here is pretty good, with 8 craft beers on draft with many, many more bottles available. Our waiter wasn't very knowledgeable about beers though, so we didn't have much help in that department. The dishes on the menu here seems to be a mishmash of Cap City Diner and the Columbus Fish Market (which I realize is no longer owned by Cameron Mitchell). The food here is good... but not great. Nothing to rave about. Cap City has better food and is less expensive. Not to mention the fact that the dishes at Cap City are 50% bigger than similar dishes at the Pearl.For appetizer, we got their jalapeno corn bread and three orders of oysters. (1 order = 3 oysters) The corn bread was good, but I don't think I would've known it had jalapenos in it, had I not read it on the menu. The oysters were good as well, but way overpriced. We paid $24 and only got 9 pieces. Ouch. In comparison, you can get a dozen oysters at the Columbus Fish Market for $26.58. It also didn't help that our waiter was clueless about oysters. We had the option of Maine, Massachusetts, PEI, British Columbia, or Virginia Oysters. He stated that with the exception of the Massachusetts ones, they were all about the same size-- so we got 3 from Maine, 3 from PEI, and 3 from British Columbia. Turns out the Maine oysters are 2.5 times the size of the PEI/BC oysters and less fishy. Come on dude.Our waiter apparently forgot that we'd only ordered appetizers at this point, so after we had already finished our oysters and corn bread, we had to flag him down to remind him that we still need to order our main course. (This is now around 45 minutes into our meal.) For our main course, our party of 4 ordered fish & chips, cuban sandwich, shrimp & grits, and the pork trio.My father had the pork trio, and was very happy with it. I had this dish myself when I dined here the first time, and this is a good dish.My mother had the shrimp & grits, but she said it was too salty and left half her plate uneaten. My mother is a lifelong member of the clean plates club, so this was unusual.My wife had the fish & chips, which was good, but painfully overpriced. The dish cost $17.99 and came with three chicken tender sized strips of fish, french fries, and coleslaw. The Sam Adams beer battered fish & chips @ Columbus Fish Market is better, bigger, and cheaper at $16.99. I got the Cuban sandwich, which was ok. The flavor was good, and the side of black bean soup was also good. But at $14 for a sandwich that was maybe a little bit bigger than a Subway 6" sub... not sure if it's worth it. In summary:-If you want an oyster bar, go to the Columbus Fish Market.-If you want a good gastropub, go to 101 Beer Kitchen, Matt the Millers, or Hudson 29. -If you want to go to a Cameron Mitchell restaurant with a similar menu (minus the oysters), go to Cap City.-If you absolutely must go to a Cameron Mitchell restaurant in the short north, go to Marcellas or Martini.I'm glad that I've dined at The Pearl, so I can say that I've been here, but I have no urge whatsoever to dine here again.

Dear Pearl,You are my favorite. Thank you for making my Columbus visit complete with your insane happy hour menu and bad ass Bloody Mary's - yes plural- because you served me a mini Milller Draft on the side, I needed to see it again.You even made my boyfriend happy with your shortrib sloppy joe. Thank you for the pot of sweet sweet pickles and chicken wing (confit)... Your special sauce is worth writing home about.Dear mom, I will bring you here soon, if you are nice to me.HELL YEAH I WILL BE BACK...

Why was my first visit to The Pearl in September 2015?! This place has some delicious oysters and a pretty legit happy hour. Not to mention, the service is pretty great, too! Their baked oysters are my favorite. My friends ordered the raw and fried oysters and enjoyed those just as much as I did the baked ones. To go along with my pre-meal, I had a Moscow Mule. It was pretty good. For my main course, I ordered the Pub Burger. It's a simple burger with cambozola cheese and tomato jam on it paired with tavern fries. It's also 1/2 price during happy hour. I had a delicious meal and drink for under $20. Can't beat that. Also, Gabby, our server, was extremely helpful. It was a great experience!

Jalapeno Spoon Bread!Great menu, big beer list, large portions, friendly staff.I had the chicken and honey bun with greens.Only one star down because the greens I had weren't rinsed well enough and I got a good amount of grit/sand in them, but that happens from time to time... the rest of the meal was awesome and I left stuffed. Very tasty desert pies, save some room.

Was so excited to get reservations on a Friday night @ 7:45pm!We got tucked back in to a cozy little corner in the back!I absolutely love this place, I felt as though I was at The Dutch in NYC! Great vibe, and friendly attentive service!It's like you are transported to somewhere outside of Columbus.I was SMITTEN to see what they had done with the space!@ the oyster bar,  loved seeing all the different kinds of oysters on ice.......and the little stools are so charming, a perfect little nook for date night.@ the "prep table" by the kitchen ...i really enjoyed watching the last touches they added to all the dishes leaving the kitchen!The menu has a nice variety of dishes, I had a hard time trying to figure out what to order! I wanted everything!We started with the Deviled Eggs ....some of the best I have ever had! And they come on this cute little egg scale :)-Baked Oysters / D-lish, they need to bottle that sauce! YUM-Jalapeno Corn Bread / came with a spoon and a side of honey & whipped cream, do I need to say more?! :)-Devils on Horseback / dates wrapped in bacon= always perfection.Dinner was a smorgasbord of food, we all decided to share 4 different dishes! Great idea to be able to try a bit of everything on the menu :)-Fish N Chips /  good,crisp, nice tarter sauce & fresh cole slaw-Braised Short Ribs / so tender, melted in your mouth goodness!-Cuban /  one of my favorites, housemade pickles, and a yummy side of spicy bean stew-Ricotta Dumplings /  a light pillow of cheese that explodes with flavor. ...PHENOMENAL!My ONLY disappointment was the Moscow Mule cocktail. About half way thru it, it had a "metal" aftertaste. Not pleasant at all. And it had way too much ice. (hence my 4 star review)...i just switched to wine and had an amazing meal!Excited to hear that they will be serving brunch soon!Can't wait to go back!

My wife and I had dinner here last night and it was very good.  We did not have reservations but we're able to sit at the oyster bar.  The place was crowded but we don't typically mind sitting at the bar when we don't have reservations.  I had the clam chowder & it was great.  I also had the fried chicken and it was good.  Large portion with a cinnamon roll so that made it better.  My wife had the baked clams & she raved about them with the crusty bread.  She also had the salmon which she said was good, not amazing.  All in all I think one of the better restaurants we have been to, not the best, but would definitely go back.

We had a reservation at 8 for a party of 2 on Friday. We got there at 7:55pm, and checked-in. There were so many people waiting inside and outside of the restaurant, and we became one of them. We were given this buzz thing and waited outside for 30 minutes. There was not much point of having a reservation.Our waiter was very friendly and nice. He explained everything in detail and was attentive. We ordered twelve 6 kinds of oysters (2 each), and got one extra. They were delicious. Drinks were good, too. Decor is cute and nice atmosphere.

Don't bother making a reservation and showing up on time. We had a reservation at 9pm, and still 3 parties ahead of us 45 minutes later on a Saturday night. The hostess just tells us people have paid and just sit at their table chatting. Meanwhile there are only 5 seats for guests waiting for their reservations. Terrible customer service

My gf and I are semi-regulars, so we've had a good portion of the menu and enjoyed a number of their cocktails. Their jalapeÌ±o "spoon: cornbread w. butter & honey is easily my favorite app, though the devils on horseback are a nice change of pace. Their burger is pretty good, but there are much better options on the menu (e.g. raw bar).  Their cocktails are consistently good, though nothing I'd recommend as a must try. The staff has always been very friendly, though they can sometimes get bogged down and can be slow to get stuff out. I prefer The Pearl during non-peak hours, though I know some don't like going out midweek or doing brunch first thing on the weekend.

Had the burger last night. It was amazing! Delicious meat (ground in house), great cheese, and some kind of sauce. I will be craving that burger abs going back for more.I also recommend the Scofflaw. And we had the Sunset Beach oysters... completely delicious.

This was my first time here. We went for Sunday brunch and was pleasantly surprised. I loved the decoration. The bar was spacious. We made reservations so there was no wait time. We were seated at our table and went over the menu. Our waiter Nick was so attentive and professional. I first ordered the deviled eggs. I asked if they tasted homemade like my mom's and he said everyone asks that question. I didn't believe him but they came out as a cute presentation. Let me just say if I could order them in bulk for Thanksgiving I would. They were sooooooooo good. I then ordered the pancakes and bacon. Wow is all I can say. I'm so glad we decided to come here. I'm not from here but when I come back it will be my first stop.

Went here last weekend and despite a horrible parking situation this place lived up to all my expectations. The jalapeÌ±o spoon bread is fantastic. The N'awlins baked oysters are even better. But perhaps the best thing we had were the short ribs. We couldn't have ended the night any better trying the brown sugar "crack" pie and Dutch Apple pieWould definitely go back again and again.

If you are looking for a place to enjoy Sunday morning brunch, look no further than The Pearl.As I was reading the menu, I instantly saw several dishes I wanted to try, but opted for the chicken and waffles. I also ordered the house smoked salmon as an appetizer.  Once the salmon arrived at my table, I could not wait a moment longer to try it and was incredibly pleased with the dish. The ratio between the salmon and scallion tartar sauce was perfect, and the deviled egg was a delightful touch. The chicken and waffles dish was also delicious, especially with the warm blueberry sauce, which set it aside from other chicken and waffle dishes I have had in the past.  The ambiance of the restaurant is classy, yet cozy and intimate with its fine decor, low lighting, and lit candles.  Something I found particularly interesting and fun is how the check is given using an old book, rather than the typical check presenter found at other restaurants.

I went for restaurant week and it was delicious. I had honestly heard mixed things about it, but I wanted to give it a try.  Reservations were made, but we were not able to be seated right away.  We waited probably an additional ten minutes after our reservation time-- no worries. You have preset options with restaurant week, which makes things easier.  I had the jalapeno spoon bread.  It's served in a skillet with butter and honey.  It was absolutely delicious and very filling.  I'm from the south and it reminded me of home...so very good. For dinner, I chose the braised short rib. It was delicious. I loved the flavors, the presentation.  The sauce accompanying the short rib was amazing.  It all went so well with the whipped mashed potatoes on the bottom of the plate. I also liked the vegetables as well.  This is likely the best meal I have had in Columbus in a very long time.I was already full, but it was time for some pie.  My friend chose a pie that was literally like brown sugar on a pie crust.  It was over the top sweet, but so so good.  The piece was smaller, but after a couple bites it became too much sweet.  I ordered the blackberry pie. It came to the table very warm in a skilled.  Think of it essentially as a mini pie.  It was great and not over the top sweet, just right.  I ate and ate and ate.  Needless to say I walked away very happy and ready to hibernate for the winter.

I had the shrimp and grits. It was very good and I know people will think this is unusual but I wish I had more grits and not as much shrimp lol. I compare most nice restaurants around Columbus to M at Miranova and for the price point I felt like The Pearl was lacking compared to M. They were kind of busy, so while our waiter was very nice it took us forever to get our food, bill, and get going.

This review is based solely off their brunch. We decided to try the pearls brunch last weekend for the first time. Started the day off with Bloody Mary's. the person I was with is a Bloody Mary snob and she raved over her drink. The house made tomato juice was delicious. When it came time to order I was torn between the waffle and chicken and the buttermilk pancakes. Our server talked me into the huevos rancheros which I wasn't even thinking about. It was a great pick. My lady got the Tavern Benny which is their take on biscuits and gravy. It was also amazing. Since I had a hard time deciding our server Nick brought out a small pancake and piece of bacon so I got the best of both worlds. It was a very nice gesture. The house made syrup is very tasty. Be prepared to spend a good amount of time at the pearl. No one seems to be in a hurry. Which was fine with me because we at Sunday brunch relaxing. Great service overall.

This place is jumping. We've been here twice. The food is delicious. Try the deviled eggs and the dates for appetizers.  Yum!   The entree portions are large. Everyone is very friendly and professional. Will definitely go back. Only one drawback, it's very noisy.

Went here for a late lunch/early dinner on NYE. The food was great, the service was great, and the dessert was great. In fact, it's the first Cameron Mitchell restaurant I actually enjoyed and would recommend for others.We ordered the smoked salmon appetizer, parmesan baked clams, and raw oysters for our appetizers. They were all great. For the entree I ordered the scallops which were on special and my husband ordered the fish and chips. He said the fish & chips were delicious and not greasy and my scallops were great. We ordered chocolate mousse for dessert along with a scoop of ice cream which was from Jeni's. It was very rich mousse, but delicious.The overall entree menu was pretty typical and nothing too special, but I would definitely go back again for their daily fish special and appetizer options.

Came here for brunch Sat morning and immediately loved the place. The staff was very welcoming and I felt right at home. My date and I had the Devils on Horseback (bacon stuffed dates), which were the highlight of the meal. Not far behind was the Jalapeno Corn Spoon Bread, which was basically like jalapeno spiced cornbread. Man, that was so creamy and the butter/honey concoction on the side was the perfect complement. I almost forgot the House Smoked Salmon, which came with this delicious Scallion Tartar Sauce. Surprisingly, one of the best peices of salmon I've eaten.Also, had Bloody Mary's that had the perfect amount of kick to it. Flavor was terrific, and I even got a Miller High Life on the side!Great date spot, ambience is relaxed, but nice enough that she'll be impressed. Good luck gentlemen.Finish your meal, and check out Big Fun afterwards. Cool comic shop with fun masks and all sorts of weird shit.  Oh, and they have a photobooth!

Not a bad option if you have reservations or don't mind a long wait. Not quite the quality I have come to expect from a Cameron Mitchell venture, but is a good option for drinks and appetizers or raw bar selections (these are a bit pricey for strange serving quantities).

Before I say anything else, this place is amazing. That should be your key takeaway. We rolled into Columbus on our way back from New Jersey to Iowa and wanted to have dinner at a nice place. Glad we made a reservation - even on a Wednesday night, the place was packed. While we waited for our table, we decided to order drinks. The pearl oyster stout for me, and a Templeton rye martini for the boyfriend. The bartender asked about his preference for bitters. She then pointed to a rotating shelf of various bottles and recommended a few different kinds. He went with chocolate bitters and they were amazing. Our server was very friendly once we were seated. Our second round of drinks included the Siberian Night stout and the Dragon's Milk Bourbon Barrel stout (at 22oz and 10% ABV it was enough for us to split reasonably).  Without hesitation - and fully trusting other reviews - we started with the jalapeÌ±o corn spoon bread. IT WAS AMAZING. YOU MUST ORDER IT. THAT IS ALL. It ended up coming out right before our entrees so we had a lot of food on our table at once (I didn't see a problem with this). The waiter immediately came over, apologized profusely because we hadn't really gotten to enjoy the spoon bread, and offered to take our entrees back to the kitchen for a bit. We declined, and he said he'd certainly comp the spoon bread for the trouble. Unexpected, but definitely wow-factor service. I thoroughly enjoyed the grilled cheese and can safely say it was the best cheese sandwich I have ever tasted. The sweetness of the pear jam and roasted squash perfectly balanced the kick of the arugula pesto and the saltiness of the Brie. I will dream about this sandwich for weeks - no joke. Boyfriend ordered the catch of the day. It was a cod filet served with clams and mussels over jasmine rice and some vegetables. He says it was perfect. The cod was cooked beautifully and was smooth and flavorful; the broth was well-seasoned; the vegetables were crisp, and the clams were done well. When describing it, he trailed off to say simply: It was yummy. The menu said fresh pie daily - save room, so obviously we had to do that. The pie of the day was a brown sugar and butter concoction. We couldn't just get one slice so I ordered apple pie a la mode. It was perfect. Great meal, great service, great ambiance. 5 stars all around.

Moscow mule drink is amazing! Short ribs were to die for!! Mashed potatoes have a hint of horseradish which sets this dish off! Also the hanger steak is delicious!! Highly recommend this place but make sure you make a reservation weeks in advance. If you walk in on a weekend you will be waiting a couple hours. Well worth the wait tho!

Finally tried this Columbus staple.  The beet salad, grilled cheese, and brown sugar pie were simply amazing.  I could have the meal every day.  The fish and chips and shrimp and grits were also good but I just enjoyed the other items more.  They also serve an excellent Moscow mule.  The classy ambience and attentive service make dining at the Pearl a luxurious experience.

Not a bad little spot, but there is definite room for improvement. A few coworkers and I visited with clients while we were in town on business. We made a reservation for 7 people. When we arrived, we were seated at two rather small tables that were pushed together. To make matters worse, the setting was in a crammed corner, making it difficult to get in and out of backside of the table. The food made up for the questionable seating. The starters and snacks were a great start. The cheese curds were perfectly crisped and the goat cheese/corn bread bake was irresistible. I had the short rib entree and it melted in my mouth as any good short rib should. The drink menu was nice but could have used more cocktails. I would have expected more whisky drinks from a restaurant with such a laid back, craft motif. Being from the Midwest, I ordered a Moscow Mule and was pretty disappointed to receive a watered down imitation. On the service side, The Pearl fared pretty well. All of our food came out in a reasonable amount of time and our server knew the menu well. My only complaints would be the cleaning of the table between courses. There were empty plates and glasses lingering even after new items were brought out. Overall, a nice place. The vibe is great and made me feel relaxed and ready for a nice meal. The sugar pie was a perfect and tasty end to the experience. Keep up the good work.

2 stars because they attempted to and did take care of my issue. We had a pretty good wait once we placed our order for brunch which was fine because we sipped and enjoyed our mid morning cocktails. When the food finally arrived it looked fantastic. Smelled fantastic. The presentation- nailed it. The bad thing; the sausage with my order was served raw. It was simply nasty. After several minutes of moving the food around on my plate I lost my appetite. Got up and went to the restroom. The server did replace it with a new order but it was to late. Good chance I will not be back. How hard is it to cook sausage? "The chef sends his apologizes"? Maybe the chef should go to Waffle House or McDonalds and re-learn how to prepare sausage. I would recommend trying out many of the other places in the short north serving brunch over the Pearl.
Came for a special birthday dinner. Maybe some hanger steak. I dunno. Never tried oysters. Wound up tossing those back all night instead. Amazing. Topped it off with some coconut pie. Boom

I had the same experience Rosalie W. had. Seems to be their tactic. I came in at 10pm, they close at 11. It was raining, so it wasn't as crowded as usual. I ordered a glass of pinot from Oregon based on the waitresses recommendation that was pretty good. I ordered baked clams and raw oysters for starters. The clams came out a bit before my meal. They had a metallic flavor, so, I wouldn't order them. At this time, one employee was obviously trying to go home, so he was sweeping right at our table. I told him to finish later cause I don't like dust getting all over my food and a broom hitting my feet while I'm eating dinner. Then our main course came out. Both main courses were good. Then the waitress brought the oysters out and apologized they were late and said they would be on the house, only when she brought the bill out, they were still on there. Exactly the same spiel and act that Rosalie W. received. Great way to ruin a nice evening.

A great standard for bringing out of towners (and just a good standard in general). To start, get some deviled eggs. They're served in a fun way. Also, the jalapeÌ±o spoon bread is ridiculous, as are the chicken wing confit. Their oyster selection has never disappointed, but their seafood tower is lacking for the price. For mains, I've loved the hanger steak, fried chicken, and Arctic char. The burger is great, but if you're not a lover of pungent cheese, ask to swap it with something different. Their drinks are great, and if you're there with a couple people, you should try one of the punch bowls.Overall a good place for dinner or brunch.

Since moving to Columbus The Pearl has quickly become my favorite restaurant. When we host guests from out of town we love showing them our new dinner spot and are never disappointed with the ambiance, wine list, food selections & dessert. We have been here a few times and tried almost everything on the menu. My favorites include: Devils on horsebackOysters - take their recommendations of the day Short Ribs Hangar Steak Park ChopBrown Sugar PieThe Brown Sugar Pie is one of the most incredible desserts I have ever tasted. It is wonderful.  I dream about it. Often. Too often that it is slightly weird. Anyways. This is a great restaurant. I recommend dinner here as brunch is not the best showing of the menu/staff capabilities.
I love the oyster night here! They have oysters from different areas and $1.5 /oyster is a pretty good deal.

I live super close so my friends and I decided to try The Pearl for Sunday brunch and couldn't have been more disappointed.  I'm fairly new to Columbus and moved here after living in two huge brunching cities - Portland, OR and DC.  This was a let down for what I'm used to.  The food was subpar and the service was worse. Our $9 brunch cocktails sat empty for 15-20 minutes at a time and the server seemed like he had better things to do than explain the menu or actually service the table.  I've heard good things about this place so maybe it was just an off day but I don't know that I'd give it another try with so many other options in the short north.

Everyone raves about The Pearl and I understand why -- it's a cute spot and a decent menu. They lost a couple stars from me by not being very vegetarian friendly and being a little pushy with the timing on the bill. I thought the Char Cauliflower and it's description sounded like a veggie dish and was so glad that I asked them to elaborate because it's actually a fish, despite not indicating that in any way on the menu. Good cocktails! Also try the jalapeÌ±o corn bread.

Pearl never disappoints! When time permits, I make sure I get here on Sunday's for Brunch. If you're a local, you know what I mean but out of towners.....this is a must before you head home.I highly recommend the 'Devils on Horseback' to get your meal started...(the fresh OJ is top notch...with vodka of course). Keep up the great work!

Classy little joint with a very cool interior complete with a raw bar. We had a late lunch with friends and just about tried everything on the menu. Favorite appetizers were the jalapeÌ±o cornbread & Devils on horseback. Oysters were delicious, but pricey. Large selection from east and west coast as well. The cheeseburger was out of site and the Cuban was a big hit.

Delicious! Everything from the coffee to the food was perfect. I got the stuff french toast and my boyfriend got the chicken and waffles... and then finished my food. Everything was cooked and seasoned perfectly. Not a huge menu but something for everyone as long as you aren't afraid of a little twist

We've been dying to try The Pearl for awhile now but have been too busy to schedule a night out on the town. So when my birthday rolled around, we made reservations for a Saturday night.It was a gorgeous day, so they had the front windows open which was awesome. The restaurant is beautiful inside and every employee I dealt with were incredibly kind. We were seated at one of the tables by the bar, which is the placement that usually irritates me but here it was a nice perch to people watch and plate watch... there were so fabulous looking dishes passing by. The cocktails. We both opted for cocktails on this night, I picked the Moscow Mule which was awesome... probably one of the best ones I've had. The fiance had a scofflaw and, even though I don't like bourbon, I would order one of these... damn tasty.Okay, the food. I listened to the majority of Yelpers and ordered the spoon bread. I am so glad that I did. Holy crap, it was good! I've had traditional Southern spoon bread and this was as close to a Southern Grandmother making a pan for you as you'll find here. It was even good as leftovers the next morning. For dinner, I ordered the Gulf shrimp boil. It was simple perfection. A dozen perfectly cooked, peel'n'eat shrimp. The fiance had the shrimp and grits which he fell in love with immediately. We were both thrilled that we came here. I don't think we'll wait for a special occasion  next time. Hmmm... maybe brunch tomorrow?

The Pearl is a my favorite date night spot for my husband and I. I love the decor, the dress of the staff, and the food is amazing. I would definitely recommend trying the deviled eggs and jalapeno corn bread.

We're here on business and was told to try Pearls, so I make a reservation and when we arrived we were seated right away. Ordered a martini which had come half full in a glass that looks like a small margarita glass. We told the manager Lori ( which I have to say is wonderful) she right away brought us 2 new ones fill to the top. We ordered the corn bread, dates wrapped in bacon and fries all were very good. For dinner we got the hanger steak, artic char, both very good the other meal was the steak, it came out not the way my colleague like it so I can't really say but they were nice enough to take it off the bill and get us the wonderful desert, Brown Sugar Pie. They treated us great and would definitely return, when we come back. Thanks Lori, we left laughing and happy.

Wonderful oysters!!!! If u order a dozen, they r gonna give you various kinds from different places ... Oysters r super fresh an wine is perfect! I luv this place !!!!  PS: waiting time is not that kinda long... They said it's about an hour 15 but we got seated about 20 mins ;)

Had dinner here earlier tonight, and below are some thoughts.Food - Was very good, but at the price it needs to be more memorable.  We had the pork trio, fried chicken, deviled eggs, and the bacon wrapped date appetizer.  Pass on the eggs, fun presentation but nothing special.Atmosphere - Beautiful with an attention to detail that goes a touch too far.  My dinning companion, while agreeing the place was beautiful thought it reminded a bit too much of having dinner in a Restoration Hardware store.Service - Excellent, simply excellent.  Our server was there when needed, without seeming to hover.  She was much more memorable than the food.If you are up for the oysters and such The Pearl may rate higher than 3 stars for you, but for my party it just wasn't somewhere we'd make a point to return.

I came here with my buddy Alex who lives in Columbus. We ordered a few dozen oysters from Nantucket, Chesapeake Bay, and Blue Point, Long Island. I was amazed at the range of oysters offered, the waitresses knowledge of the oysters, and the ambiance. I was truly impressed.Located downtown, not far from OSU, this is a perfect spot for drinks and oysters. The staff is very nice and ambiance is perfect. The first warm night of April with weather in the mid 70s. The windows were open to the street and the scene was lovely.
Love their style, the atmosphere, the good vibage, and most importantly; their exquisite twist on awesome dishes- a foodies land mine. Good service, great work ethic. Definitely a returning customer.

This is by far my favorite of the Mitchell restaurants I have tried. Parking is tricky. I tried the spoon bread, tater tots, fish and chips (perch), fried chicken, and oysters. All were delicious (and some of the best I've ever had). Price was appropriate. Atmosphere was trendy and upscale with an overall nice vibe. Service was solid. I'd certainly return and recommend it to my friends! Try anything you like and I'm sure you won't be disappointed.
Crowded and overpriced. Food was mediocre at best, and mason jars for water and books to hold the bills were gimmicky, not charming. Disappointing - you can do a lot better than this in town.

The Pearl is one of my favorite Columbus restaurants due to its top notch dishes and friendly wait staff. I have been here twice and the wait staff is always the bright spot; very friendly and extremely attentive. Food has always came out very quickly.I have tried a number of dishes here and they are all outstanding. Very flavorful dishes coupled with a great presentation. Some of the portions from the oyster bar are small so just know that if you go that route. One gripe I have is the change in the cheese curd appetizer between my two most recent visits. First time they were amazing!!!! However this most recent time i got them there was barely any cheese at all some of the "curds" was just hollow breading. Oh and the cocktails are out of this world. One of the best Manhattans I have had in Columbus and my GF loves the Moscow Mule here.Overall this is a great place to entertain clients, have a few drinks, or take a date!

Really loved this place. Just had my first visit to Columbus and this restaurant was a pleasant surprise. The bartenders know what they are doing and the service was amazing. Our waitress, Eva, was attentive, easy to work with, and fun to talk to. The food was very impressive and you will not regret getting dessert.

First time at the Pearl and it was very disappointing. There was only one bartender, and she was so busy it took us over 15 minutes to get a drink order in. The oysters came fairly quickly and were good. We had completely forgotten we ordered meatballs because they took so long to arrive. The bartender then forgot to ring in our second order of drinks, so we went somewhere else. If the service is this bad on a Wednesday, I cant imagine it on the weekend. I don't blame the bartender, it's not her fault she had no help. Probably won't go back.

GREAT customer service!!!  My husband and I came out for our first date after a new addition to our family.  ;-)  With the little guy at home with the grandparents, we went out for brunch, determined to have a good time.  Some of you know I have a nut allergy and I let the server know - wouldn't you know, the very dish I wanted (chicken and waffles) was made with peanut oil.  Now, supposedly peanut oil doesn't have the proteins that most people are allergic to, but with previous near death experiences I wasn't taking a chance.  But I REALLY wanted the chicken and waffles.  Without even asking, the server informed me that they could cook it at nearby Marcella's without the peanut oil, but since it was brunch time, I'd have to wait 40 minutes.  We decided to get drinks and starters (spoonbread and oysters) and wait.  My husband got the poutine.  Thirty minutes later, I had my chicken and waffles, and he had his poutine.  And it was glorious.  SO worth it.  And I really DO appreciate the extra effort they went through to make my dish.  The spoonbread was good, and the oysters excellent.  My husband said the poutine was a little on the salty side, but good.  And the mimosas were excellent - I don't like mine too sweet, and these were wonderfully tart.It was a wonderful first date out.  :-)  Thanks, the Pearl!

We went to the Pearl for Happy Hour- Drink Specials were great, the food was good-ok. We had; salmon-good portion size nice flavorchicken wings-unique good flavorOysters-just ok. Very small and I'm not sure if that's just the season or if they use the smaller one's for HH. Still, good flavor, The tiny little guys were swimming in a butter sauce that was to die for.Deviled eggs-don't waste your money-nothing special, at all.Cuban sandwich-this left much to be desiredCorn Bread-delicious but tasted like jiffyOverall-great atmosphere, great HH, but I doubt if I'd go for dinner.
Awesome atmosphere. Definitely a "foody" menu. But everything on the menu is awesome. Another great restaurant by Cameron Mitchell.

If this was closer to my house, I would be a regular. The cornbread is probably the best I've had (outside my home, of course) and every menu item I have tried (especially the shrimp and grits) has been phenomenal. Great service, very attentive.

I'll start with the good:Fantastic drinks! Modern atmosphere! Cute and friendly service!Hands down best Bloody Mary!! (Minus the pepperoni garnish- a heads up would be nice) I'm vegetarian and did not think to request a "vegetarian" Bloody Mary.Great Moscow mule. Great spicy corn bread.The servers I have had there are very attentive and knowledgeable. I love love the atmosphere and the staff attire. The best and now ties are so hip and classy. I love the old-timey vibe. And, once again amazing drinks. It seems like all the pretty people in Columbus gather here. Good times!The Bad:I took one star away for the ricotta balls. They were bland. Also, they need more good vegetarian options. What about an acorn squash filled with a couscous com concoction of sautÌ©ed spinach and garlic mash?? Something satisfying like that. Also, some more options that aren't as heavy would balance out the menu. The Ugly:Another star away because I am a vegetarian and only have 1 option there. A  mediocre salad that is 20$ really doesn't do it for me.Anyway, if you like oysters, drinks and seafood....its a good place. I don't like seafood -so its not for me. The menu needs to be more diversified. Love getting a drink here though, sans pig meat! Haha

One of the best meals of my life. Cocktails and appetizers were fantastic, but really was impressed by the wings. I grew up working in my aunt and uncle's restaurant and to this day, the wings at The Pearl are the only close to as good as the friend chicken we made there. Whatever process they go through is magical. For my entrÌ©e, I chose the short rib. Please, for the love of your taste buds, do this. They gave me a knife, but it was pointless as the short rib was so tender and moist (who doesn't love "moist" things?) that it nearly fell apart as my fork touched the meat. Our server was unreal good and - as my wife and I were on a date - gave us a wonderful evening with the appropriate chattiness and also allowing us to spend time alone enjoying each other's company. It was a treat that I'll be remembering for some time.

I finally got around to trying the Pearl for the first time on Sunday. I know, I know that is probably way too long to have waited, but c'est la vie I suppose. It was worth the visit though as I found the experience enjoyable.I ended up having a pint of the Pearl Oyster Stout as my opener. I had tried the beer once before as it's brewed just a ways down the street at North High Brewing. I believe it's a beer that they make specifically for this restaurant. Along with the beer I decided to order the Pub Burger. The Cambozola cheese topping went exceptionally well with the tomato jam topping that came on the side. The fries that come as the side dish are incredibly delicious and are served in a portion that you will simply be unable to finish (especially since the burger is rather generously sized as well).I left with my appetite sated and my tasted buds in delight. I'm told that there is also a rather lovely brunch here that I'll have to return to try on another occasion.

Great atmosphere! Went here with a work group sound level was not overwhelming. Menu selection was good for the entire group from Vegan to Carnavor. I had the Hanger Steak with Kimshee Rice I ordered Medium Rare and I felt it was a little to on the rare side but there was not a bite left on my plate. The interior was trendy and hip. The staff were all very friednly. The only negative was I ordered a drink and the glass had a crack in it and instead of replacing my drink they poured the drink from the glass with the crack into the new glass. If that had not happened I would have given 5 stars. I would recommend and revisit this location again when in the area.

My sister who attends OSU and my coworkers only had amazing things to say, but we left our meal incredibly disappointed. The service was bad - we saw our server maybe once before she shoved our check across the table, never asking if we'd like another drink or if the food was any good. And the food - another disappointment. My sister ordered the ricotta dumplings which tasted like they'd been reheated 4 times (she'd had them before and loved them). I had the short rib which was better than the dumplings, but still underwhelming. I came in with high expectations, but won't be returning any time soon.

I like this place, I really do.  It has a whole lot of hype around it and it's constantly packed full with hipsters, but it's ok.  It's generally loud and energetic as far as ambiance goes, which is nice every now and then.  It's clear that they put a lot of thought into their menu development, and the bartenders mix some mean cocktails.
Pearl was very busy and the wait was long, even for the bar. The food was good, but service was slow. The visit was made worth it by dessert, the homemade pie is incredible.
Oysters were very fresh and the dressed crab was great. Sat at the raw bar and the service wasn't very great but I still really enjoyed my meal.

I've been wanting to check out The Pearl since I moved to Columbus almost 2 years ago and finally made my way there yesterday for brunch. To say I was disappointed is an understatement. I'd heard so many great things about this place and at the end of brunch I was underwhelmed. The restaurant itself was pretty cool: the decor was cute, the space was used well, and I liked the open kitchen area. However, the food and service was subpar. Our server greeted us but did not offer up the specials and/or mention the omelette of the day. Our drinks were empty and we had to track him down to order another. And finally, the food was nothing to write home about. My meal, the huevos rancheros was bland. The tortillas came on the side and were brought out wrapped in foil but they stuck together making it impossible to roll them up in a more traditional huevos rancheros style. My dining companion ordered the chicken and waffles per our server's suggestion, yet her waffle was overlooked and stayed rock hard even when she added a ton of maple syrup. Maybe brunch just isn't their strong suit, but since I'm not a fan of oysters, I will likely not return.
Great location, great food, great service. Love the jalapeÌ±o cornbread. The Pearl is great for drinks or a sit down dinner.

Every time I go here I think the staff is very nice and attentive but the food is mediocre and tiny for a huge price.  I am a small person and don't eat very much so for me to think the portions are small is a big deal.  The food is not bad but so not worth the huge bill attached to it.  There are too many better deals with amazing food in the Short North to keep going here.

Took a friend from out of town here because 1. We both wanted good seafood. 2. I hadn't had oysters since I lived in Charleston, SC (over two years). So we chose Pearl and it was amazing. I called early afternoon the day of to see if I could by chance get a reservation, but they were booked. The lady on the phone was very nice and told us to just come and they usually can fit walk-ins in or we can eat at the bar. Once we got there, the guy at the entrance didn't seem to want to help because he said they don't seat walk ins so we would need to wait for a bar seat or sit at the raw bar. So, it was slightly confusing based on the conversation I had on the phone prior. We weren't In a Hurry but the stars aligned and we only waited for about 10 minutes and got a bar seat. Both bartenders were very helpful in answering any questions we had, but also very friendly as well. We order edit he dates wrapped in bacon and they were fantastic, we both could have eaten a pound of them!I ordered two orders of the Baked Oysters (1 order only has 3 oysters). They were baked with a spicy seasoning. I absolutely loved them. My friend ordered the baked clams and those were just as great. Be sure to also try the Moscow mule, it's their most popular drink and is refreshing and delicious!I love the atmosphere and the feel of the place, it's relaxed but not too relaxed. Don't feel like you can't wear jeans there based from pricing... Which is the only downfall. I paid $22.00 for 6 oysters. I knew they would be good so It didn't hurt too much, but as all of you who eat oysters, 6 doesn't cut it. After my six oysters, a glass of wine, Moscow mule, and a split price of the dates... I spent $50.00 on myself. So, I took myself out on a date, haha. I will return, but probably only for special occasions! All in all it was a wonderful experience!

Fantastic cocktails and some cool menu items like bacon wrapped dates that are to die for. I've been stuck on the Moscow Mules the last few times and have had several friends have the Bloody Mary's which they've said are one of the best in the city. Favorite entree so far has been the pub burger. Delicious flavor and great quality of meat. Atmosphere has a cool vibe and I've eaten dinner and brunch so far and had a great experience both times. Parking as with most places can be a pain so be patient or take a cab in.

Tried The Pearl out a few weeks ago for a Sunday brunch. First of all, I loved the dÌ©cor and ambiance of the place. Very cozy and comfortable. Tables are a bit close together, but that really didn't bother me. Had the devils on horseback for a starter. They were very tasty, but I think a bit overpriced for such a small portion. I believe there were only 4 of them. And not very big. But, still tasted great. I decided on the Tavern Benny and my bfriend got the Chicken and Waffles. Great portion sizes and everything tasted delicious. Only complaint was that my food was not piping hot. It was warm. Would have been better if hotter! Oh, and the Bloody Mary's are soooo good!
Decent food. Atmosphere was not anywhere near other Mitchell restaurants. Will not be back.

I went there due to a spot on Food Network featuring their Devils on Horseback. I was underwhelmed. Their happy hour deals are great, as are their oysters, but if I were to go back, I would order the spoon bread and house smoked salmon. The couple next to me had that and they raved about it!
For a restaurant that calls itself 'Oyster Room' would expect to see more oyster dishes offered on the menu.  Pleasant and efficient service. With reservation was seated immediately.

Best brunch I've had in a looong time! Elderflower fizz was perfect way to wake up on a Sunday. Tater tots to start followed by the Bananas Foster French Toast...best of both the savory and sweet worlds. Absolutely delicious. Reservations recommended.

What can I say about the Pearl that hasn't already been said?  We have been here on several occasions both for dinner and brunch, and have left every time feeling euphoric over our dining experience.The last time we went to the Pearl, I made reservations through OpenTable and asked them to have a bottle of champagne chilled and waiting at our table since it was my best friend & fiance's 30th birthdays.  Everything was perfect, and they were so surprised when we walked in!  Their deviled eggs are some of the best we have ever had, as well as the devils on horseback.From their drink menu to the atmosphere to the service, the Pearl is a great place to go for any special occasion (even if that means a regular Tuesday night!)

It was okay... Just okay. Went for happy hour. Oysters had some shells in them, they brought us less oysters than we ordered, forgot some of our small plates and we really had to stay on top of them for it. The smoked salmon was okay but not flavorful and was basically a giant non delicate chunk of fish, with toasted wonder bread. Chicken wing confit, literally just chicken wings. JalapeÌ±o skillet corn bread was pretty good. Nothing was outright bad, and nothing was surprisingly good. The server was okay taking things off our bill that never showed up... But still not good that we had that much trouble just to get what we ordered. If friends were going Id go again rather than miss out, but I wouldn't recommend going out of your way for this place.

I love this restaurant. I chose The Pearl for my birthday, and couldn't have been happier. The ambiance is delightful, and the wait staff are amazing. I love the boiled eggs and the broiled shrimp for appetizers. I've tried many different dishes, and I always come back to the Braised Short Rib. The desert menu is always evolving, and make sure you try a Moscow Mule.

Good atmosphere but over priced and entree is lacking quality. Cinnamon roll was dry burger was mediocre and appetizers were small. Drinks were also not impressive and staff was slow or under staffed because Service lacked. Lame.

Excellent.Smoked Salmon was great start and very tasty.  Great selection of beers and wine as well.  Main course was the hangar steak w/ fried kimchi... was pleased overall (steak was more medium then rare- but good).Like deviled eggs? Be sure the have one here.  Would visit again.

Great food and excellent service.  We didnt have a reservation on a saturday night during comfest. At first they only offered the bars for seating, but then sat us at a table. Highlights were the jalapeno spoon corn bread, devils on horseback for starters and confit pork chops with mashed potatoes and brussel sprouts. Flavors,  aromas and ambience were all amazing!

Very good food, great atmosphere. The bartenders are actual bartenders and make there own, unique drinks. Moscow mule is good as are the Martinis. Wine selection is a little lacking if your looking to buy by the glass. Minimal oyster selection, I think they had 4 types. I assume the limited options were to maintain freshness. They were good and served right. Overall a nice place.

You can never go wrong with dining at the Pearl. Weather it be brunch on the weekend (The Tavern Benny is amazing) or dinner durning the week (The oyster are always delicious and fresh). I recommend the Chesapeake bays. Drinks are always good and the servers are energetic and passionate about the place.

I was very excited to learn yesterday, that we would be dining at The Pearl for dinner. This has been one of my top places to visit in Columbus and for it to be a surprise was just wonderful!We arrived, handed our keys to the valet and headed inside. The decor is beautiful and the floor is SLIPPERY. Please be careful* It was quite loud, but that may have just been the party of people I was with. I wish I could apologize to the table beside us, for the type of things said at our table last night *oh the embarrassment*.Anyways- We sat down and ordered the oysters. We did the flight of oysters, that I don't even think was on the menu. It was four dozen oysters, two of the Chesapeake oysters, one each of two different types that I can no longer remember. The oysters were raw, so sliminess is to be expected. What I didn't expect were the huge chunks of shell with my raw, slimy oysters. I seriously almost chipped a tooth on two different occasions! We also had the raw clams, which in my opinion, were better tasting than the oysters, but still had shell in them. Maybe if they would take a little more time to shuck them, less shell would be digested.. but I digress.We had the baked oysters and baked clams. They were both very good (I tend to prefer my shellfish cooked), the oysters are spicy- be aware of that. The sauce the clams were baked with was easily the best thing I tasted all night. We all sopped up the sauce in the bread that came with the clams.While the boys all ate boil and peel shrimp, I had the colossal crab (due to a very unfortunate and sad shrimp allergy). It was very good, sweet, creamy, and huge beautiful pieces of crab claw. Maybe this was my favorite thing all night. The boys all drank a little too much by the end, (after three G&T doubles, a shot of tequila and an Irish car bomb each) I am surprised our waiter didn't throw them all out! (do you see where the embarrassment is coming from now?)For five people, we spent over $400 with tip. I left hungry, because honestly, a few raw oysters and couple bites of crab does not equate to a full meal, and with a huge hole in my pocket. Maybe we will be back on someone else's dime next time.

An all-around  great experience. The ambience is fun and pub-modern, the service is awesome, the craft drinks are quality, and the food is indulgent. We had the seafood tower and it did not disappoint! Also, deviled eggs and dates wrappedin bacon? Delicious!

Ate here just last Night and ordered the Nawlins oysters and was very disappointed.  $11 for 3 small not so tasty oysters  just because they are spicy doesn't make them Cajun or Nawlins style.    Today I'm in NOLA and am enjoying half dozen of tasty oyster quadruple the size for the same price!! Overall I give this place 3 stars because drinks were ok. The Cod and quinoa was pretty tasty and Id visit again for a light bite or lunch.

The brunch took a while but was definitely worth waiting for. I ate the jalapeÌ±o bacon omelet(omelet of the day) with an arugula salad and my friend ate the tavern burger with a fried egg. The food all tasted great and would recommend anyone to go for Brunch.
This review is based on the food. Atmosphere and service are great. The food is overpriced for the quality and quantity you receive.

While visiting Columbus on business, a local friend took us to the Pearl. The food was excellent! I had the Atlantic Char which was cooked to perfection and had a delicious cauliflower side and sauce. I also could not resist trying the oysters. The Pearl has a great selection of oysters. They were fresh and tasty. Nice surprise in the midwest! The Pearl also makes an awesome Manhattan. I had to have two.My dining partner had the fried chicken and said it was the best he'd ever had outside of the south. And it was a huge portion.The atmosphere was lively. We were seated in the back and the noise level was fine. I look forward to going back. The seafood tower is calling to me!

Holy cow!  This place is incredible!  I came on resturant week and got their deal for $30. I got the cornbread, short rib and the banana cream pie. Hands down, the best on all three I've ever had. The short rib was so tender I couldn't even keep it on the fork!!!!!  Cornbread had the perfect texture with just the flavor of jalapeÌ±o and sweet butter and honey. To top it off the banana cream pie was perfect!  Killer vibe, incredible food, drinks, and amazing service on a busy Saturday. It's a bit pricy, but man worth every penny!
They killed it. Great oysters. Excellent pate. If that is how you spell it. Seriously all the food is good.

We sat on the bar, we just had a very light dinner and only drank a glass of the cheapest white wine each and we ended up paying 80 bucks. The food was good but not great, just average. I have eaten a lot better on cheaper places. It is not worth the wait and even less the price. Go here if you do not care at all about your finance and if nothing else on Short North is available. Enough said.

Just another CMR restaurant. The food/drinks/service is great as always. Oyster bar? They don't have an oyster bar for claiming to be an oyster bar. They have about 5 different oysters to choose from but they are priced at $10 for 3 (raw). Oyster bars are all about one thing (its in the name). They rest of the menu offers gastropub food including:The hanger steak with kimchi fried rice (highly suggested but the hanger steak being the cheapest cut of beef shouldn't cost $26)Devils on horseback (probably the best thing on the menu, dates wrapped in bacon)Good selection of craft beers on tap! St. Bernardus apt 12!

I have never in my life written an angry review, but then again I have never had a restaurant actually make me angry.  It's not the staff or the serviceable food but the complete disdain for design and comfort and aesthetics that is infuriating about Pearl.  Even if half the tables were removed, Pearl would still be an overstuffed, ugly, unappealing, rectangular Walmart of a restaurant, whose too obvious goal is to sell as much food as possible to as many people as possible -- to make money.  There is NO regard for beauty, charm, visual appeal, or design. Other than the comfy mini-oasis in the waiting area by the front window, I challenge customers to find a spot anywhere in the restaurant with an enjoyable feel and a pleasing view. The real grief about this place is that a prime location in the Short North is condemned to mediocrity for years to come.

What isn't there to love? The atmosphere is on point. The food is good and the service is awesome. I've had clam chowder before but nothing beats The Pearl's clam chowder. One sip of their soup and you will be hooked.

If you love great martinis and oysters, you must visit The Pearl. My fiance and I have quite a different taste in food and we both love coming to The Pearl for dinner. Between the two of us, I think we have tried just about everything on the menu and have NEVER been disappointed! I love the old-timey atmosphere and the friendly service.
Adorable charm!  As an oyster fan, these were phenomenal.  Also the deviled egg appetizer is a MUST.

I almost gave The Pearl 5 stars, but I guess I'll wait for my next visit to bump it up a notch.First, there's nothing like it in Columbus. Upon entering, it felt like a smaller version of Chicago's Paris Club, minus the Frenchy bits and add in American coastal preppy bits. Dark woods, casual, some industrial touches. The waitstaff is in casual-cool uniforms: think gingham and plaid shirts, wool vests, and the hostesses all in black with matching cool-luxe scarves. One of the restaurant areas features a cool marble bar-- I think this was the "oyster" area but I didn't inspect closely. On a large industrial cart with a butcher's block top was some kind of station that almost looks like a performance area. It seemed to be the finish/garnish stop for the plates before they come out. Food is definitely on parade here. I had as much fun looking at what was coming out as I did eating my dishes. It looks like a lot of thought goes into the presentation of the food.The menu is mostly American comfort food, with Eastern Seaboard themes and a few West Coast trends. We ordered oysters and deviled eggs to start. The deviled eggs came out on this adorable egg-weighing device like you might see at a small farm. And oh man-- they were freaking delicious. A deviled egg at a restaurant is a bit of a canary-in-the-mine test. If a restaurant can make a deviled egg worth ordering, it's a good sign. These were worth ordering, both because of preparation and presentation.We shared two entrees for our mains: the fried chicken (based largely on Bryant M's recommendation) and the hanger steak with fried egg, fried rice, and kimchi (I've said it  before, Korean is the new Japanese). Of the two, the chicken was the clear winner. When the plate was first set on the table, I thought the chicken was overdone, but the crispy skin looks dark more from the spice blend than from the fryer, methinks. It was phenomenal. The collard greens were phenomenal (I like a vinegary bite). The sweet roll on the side was PHENOMENAL. I'm not really a fan of sweet pastries, but the conversation stopped dead in its tracks while I had my special moment with this sweet roll. I was kind of pissed I had to share. The hanger steak was good. Not as good as the chicken, but good. The meat was cooked perfectly, but the kimchi/fried rice needs a better balance. It was too salty, maybe. Needed more veg in the rice (I spied a few mushrooms). The egg could have been runnier-- if it were runnier it might have chilled out the saltiness a bit.I agree with Stephanie K. that some items are a little over priced. The oysters were 3 for $8, which is definitely on the high end. I'd be interested to see if they start having a weekly special on oysters because if so, I'm there. Some of the menu items (like the Cuban) looked overpriced as well-- you can get a good Cuban for much less. Just use your noodle and read the ingredients list on the menu-- some things are priced fairly, but be smart about what you're really paying for. We also got our drank on. I ordered the gin fizz and the Moscow mule. The gin fizz was made with Watershed gin, and it was more light and refreshing than any other cocktail I've ever had. Sometimes I'm wary of Watershed's strong signature aftertaste when I'm drinking it with any kind of food, but the bartender somehow mellowed out that finish with the egg white or whatever. The Moscow mule was also bright and refreshing, but it had so much shaved ice in it that I had trouble getting to the last quarter of that precious liquid. My table mate's apple bourbon punch was neither too apple-y nor too bourbon-y. I want to order a bowl of it for the table when I can get back to The Pearl with a large group. The timing of our drinks was horrible, though. It took a long time to get the first round. Even though we ordered the drinks first, we were through our apps before we got our drinks. Our waiter did explain that it took so long because the bartender needed to remake mine, which I appreciated, but still. Then, our second round came after we were finished with the meal despite ordering it much earlier, so that second round became dessert. The bill comes in an old book, where patrons sign in the end papers. Super cute idea. Kinda adds to the Hampton-y prep vibe, like these books were left in someone's family summer home for decades. Anyway, I had a lovely evening at The Pearl. Not only do I want to come back again and again, but I'm inspired to work through (most) of the menu. I felt like I was on vacation.

Might be the best brunch in Columbus - house smoked salmon and a bloody mary. The food is definitely a treat, you'll see for dinner the menu isn't cheap. But it's SO good and the inside decor is amazing. Brunch is reasonably priced and perfect for a couple or group. We're going here to celebration a graduation in May - that's saying a lot! Cameron Mitchel does it again.

I've been to Pearl a few times. I think the food is great, though the service neither bad nor particularly great. Last time I went we got fried curds, deviled eggs, and the spoon cornbread for appetizers. The curds were ridiculously addictive and I also got some new orleans baked oysters that were flavorful too. My entree was the shrimp and grits - super savory and intense, but I was so full from everything I ate before. I got a complimentary dessert for my birthday - Apple blackberry cobbler which, I must say, was incredible reheated a couple hours later when my stomach could accommodate it...I must say Pearl is pretty good.

I'm sorry Cap City, I think the Pearl might just have unseated you for my favorite CM restaurant. I still love you, I swear. I just think maybe it is time we see other people or you get the brie grilled cheese. All the great things you expect from a Cameron Mitchell restaurant: attention to detail, excellent and friendly service, innovative foods, a solid menu, clever theme, beautiful decor... I couldn't have been more pleased with my visit, considering I wasn't the one paying. Very impressive considering the growing pains most restaurants experience their first few months.My cohort and I started with the pot o pickles, the oven baked oysters and the spoon bread. All very good, loved the pickles that are made in house- but have to say my spoon bread is a little better... I will even give you the recipe if you want. Not complaining though. For dinner, I had the brie grilled cheese, which I saved up calories for all week and which cannot be described adequately in words though I will try. On brioche, with brie, pear preserves and a little pesto. Paired wonderfully with an arugula salad. It was quite possibly the tastiest grilled cheese I have ever experienced and I will do it again. Had a glass of wine, which was expensive but a heavy pour. The bill was actually surprisingly reasonable- the grilled cheese is only $12.00. They have punch bowls to share booze if you have 4 or so people.  Must go back to try.Great idea, very laid back- city meets southern charm. Love it, love it, love it. Make reservations.

The Pearl was spot-on from opening week and has been ever since. I've been in here a handful of times and each time has been easy, delicious, and consistently great.The interior of the restaurant gets major props. It's so comfy and inviting while still being hip and well thought out for its decor. The waitstaff has been super friendly and helpful, there when you need something but not hovering or in the way.I've never had a bad meal here. Some are better than others, but all the meals would be at least a 4 star. For appetizers you can't go wrong with the crispy fried curds, japaleno cornbread, or devils on horseback. I'm not an oyster fan so I can't give an opinion on half of their namesake. As far as dinner goes the Southern Fried Chicken is awesome (and the sticky bun that comes with it is really the grand prize of this meal). Ricotta dumplings are tasty, as is the brie and pear grilled cheese. A friend had the Pork Trio and said it was good but not amazing and that is the biggest complaint I've heard about this restaurant.The cocktails and drinks are great.
